{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Fisher-Price is putting a virtual toy museum on Instagram with 90 exhibits tapping into nostalgia for a new spin on experimental e-commerce — see inside","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/fisher-price-virtual-museum-with-vintage-toys-and-gift-shop-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8856c7ea23a5001903d8ac?format=jpeg\" alt=\"1960s CHATTERTELEPHONE\" height=\"2460\" width=\"3280\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Chatter Telephone.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mattel</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Toy manufacturer Fischer Price is celebrating its 90th anniversary with a virtual Instagram museum.</li>\n<li>The brand is featuring 90 toys, with selections from each decade.</li>\n<li>The virtual experience even includes a gift shop.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Toy manufacturer Fisher-Price is celebrating its 90th anniversary in a very 2020 way, with a <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/fisherprice.toymuseum/\">virtual museum</a>. The museum lives on Instagram, taking viewers through some of the most popular toys of each decade the brand has been around, leaning heavily on nostalgia.</p><p>Virtual experiences are having a moment recently, with most in-person activities on hold or significantly altered because of the coronavirus pandemic. Companies have tried to recoup some lost revenue through virtual workshops, tours, and even <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/virtual-food-travel-experiences\">wine tastings.</a> Nearly 4,000 <a href=\"https://artsandculture.google.com/search/streetview?project=streetviews\">museums</a> have also made <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-visit-museums-online-through-google-while-social-distancing-2020-3\">exhibits available online</a>, including The Guggenheim and The Met.</p><p>Parent company Mattel launched this museum and gift shop right as many are starting to think about holiday shopping. The coronavirus-induced recession has decreased consumer spending and thrown more than eight million into <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/15/us/politics/federal-aid-poverty-levels.html?smid=tw-share\">poverty.</a></p><p>However, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-ecommerce-sales-grew-by-nearly-a-third-q2-2020-8\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"ef2f3d0a5243618b6582afddeac7d6fc\">e-commerce sales</a> increased by nearly a third in Q2 as the pandemic kept many people inside and online shopping became more convenient than ever. With a year-over-year increase of 44.5%, e-commerce is a $211.5 billion industry, so the virus' impact on holiday shopping remains to be seen.</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tUpon opening the virtual Instagram museum, there's a cute drawing of a museum exterior.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f885e502a400c0019debd77?format=jpeg\" alt=\"MUSEUM_LOGO\" height=\"2339\" width=\"3119\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Virtual museum.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mattel</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe 1938 Snoopy Sniffer was one of Fisher-Price's most popular toys, and predates the Peanuts cartoon by over a decade. Vintage models now go for more than $70 on reseller sites.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f88615f2a400c0019debd8f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"1930s SNOOPYSNIFFER\" height=\"2998\" width=\"3998\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Snoopy Sniffer.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mattel</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://artsandculture.google.com/asset/snoopy-sniffer-toy/WwHFeEwnO5lAlg?hl=en\">Google Arts and Culture</a>, <a href=\"https://www.ebay.com/i/223476540896?chn=ps&#38;norover=1&#38;mkevt=1&#38;mkrid=711-117182-37290-0&#38;mkcid=2&#38;itemid=223476540896&#38;targetid=935065065987&#38;device=c&#38;mktype=pla&#38;googleloc=9005677&#38;poi=&#38;campaignid=10460106906&#38;mkgroupid=106723176227&#38;rlsatarget=pla-935065065987&#38;abcId=2146001&#38;merchantid=113442341&#38;gclid=CjwKCAjw5p_8BRBUEiwAPpJO67ebprIP2wtNdKUVB7xsk-p_9S5mTCk_3mDme6Ee2tC8NfPrsLbLGRoCvPcQAvD_BwE\">Ebay</a></em></p>\n\tThe Coaster Boy wooden toy of 1941 was only produced for one year. Each virtual exhibit gets a tiny set to show off it's characteristics.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8862442a400c0019debd96?format=jpeg\" alt=\"1940s COASTERBOY\" height=\"2749\" line.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8863092a400c0019debd9b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"1950s SAFETYSCHOOLBUS\" height=\"2571\" width=\"3429\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Safety School Bus\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mattel</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t1957's Corn Popper is the all time longest running toy in Fisher-Price's line.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img available today.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f88793bd2607800193419c5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"2000s KASEYTHEKINDERBOT\" height=\"2577\" width=\"3437\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Kasey the Kinderbot,.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mattel</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe Musical Lion Baby Walker epitomizes the 2010s with this classic meme format.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img class=\"copyright\">Mattel</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tNo virtual museum experience would be complete without a gift shop, so of course Fisher-Price included one.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img imagery.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f885407ea23a5001903d89d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"LunchboxApple_FisherPrice_GiftShop\" height=\"1080\" width=\"1080\" shop.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mattel</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tA Fun Jet t-shirt is very 70s, in an homage to the vintage toy.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img 407ea23a5001903d89d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn59@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-25-575_28a21d34d685912c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f887b1c9e9fe400190098b2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn55@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-24-618_e481c22db68501fe.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f885406ea23a5001903d89c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn7@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-17-841_94e68c24a7a42380.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f887aa49e9fe400190098b1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn35@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-35-980_798dd1629d892887.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=R_sTErXMzfk:EFjDUEVkeCE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn68@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-27-350_aae25b6bca7ea4ff.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=R_sTErXMzfk:EFjDUEVkeCE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn66@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-16-877_3637460ef119990b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=R_sTErXMzfk:EFjDUEVkeCE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn7@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-23-417_6f01a64c0b7f8b27.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/R_sTErXMzfk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn100@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-17-881_6e35b967a59806b7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520912},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"'Masks work? NO': Twitter removes tweet by White House coronavirus adviser that says face coverings are not effective against COVID-19","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/tweet-removed-dr-scott-atlas-masks-dont-prevent-covid-19-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8c428ac21cfb0019468a65?format=jpeg\" alt=\"scott atlas\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dr. Scott Atlas has become a regular presence at White House coronavirus briefings. He&#39;s seen addressing the media on September 28, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/dr-scott-atlas-advisor-to-president-donald-trump-delivers-news-photo/1277213737?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">Tasos Katopodis/Getty</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Twitter removed a tweet by White House coronavirus adviser Dr. Scott Atlas who claimed that face coverings were not effective in stopping the spread of the coronavirus.</li>\n<li>The doctor, who joined the coronavirus task force in August, tweeted&#160;on Saturday: \"Masks work? NO\", alongside a link to an article that argued against the success of face coverings.</li>\n<li>Atlas told Newsweek he had appealed the decision, adding: \"Twitter seems to be censoring the science if it goes against their own goals of public indoctrination.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Twitter has removed a tweet from White House coronavirus adviser Dr. Scott Atlas who claimed that face coverings are not effective in stopping the virus's spread.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/scott-atlas-trump-coronavirus-diagnosis-wont-change-wh-pandemic-strategy-2020-10\">Atlas, who has previously spoken out against lockdowns,</a> <a href=\"https://twitter.com/swatlashoover?lang=en\">tweeted</a>&#160;on Saturday: \"Masks work? NO\", alongside a link to an article that argued against the success of face coverings.</p><p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/swatlashoover?lang=en\">He later followed up this tweet by writing</a>: \"That means the right policy is [President Trump's] guideline: use masks for their intended purpose - when close to others, especially hi risk.\" Dr. Atlas also added that he believes widespread mask mandates are not needed.</p><p>Twitter has since removed his original tweet.</p><p>The social media platform has been <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-changes-election-political-misinformation-policy-2020-10\">cracking down on misinformation</a> in recent months, posting <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-labels-trump-tweet-saying-he-has-coronavirus-immunity-as-misleading-2020-10\">warning labels on controversial tweets</a> and,<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-locked-president-trump-account-shared-email-2020-10\">most recently, even temporarily blocking President Trump's account.</a></p><p>Under the new misinformation policy, Twitter prohibits sharing false or misleading content related to COVID-19, which could lead to harm.</p><p>According to a company spokesperson, Atlas's tweet was in violation of this policy, <a href=\"https://www.newsweek.com/twitter-removes-mask-tweet-white-house-adviser-1540081\">Newsweek reported.</a></p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Scott W. Atlas  (@SWAtlasHoover) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1317466976651038720?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 17, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>\"Twitter seems to be censoring the science if it goes against their own goals of public indoctrination,\" Atlas told Newsweek in an email, adding that he has since appealed the company's decision.</p><p>He also said that he made sure to \"specifically and immediately\" clarified in the second tweet that the correct policy was \"use masks when one cannot socially distance.\"&#160;</p><p>Atlas has a background in neuroradiology, not infectious diseases. He joined the White House coronavirus task force in August after becoming a fixture on Fox News.</p><p>He has previously been critical of top US infectious-<wbr>disease expert, Dr. Anthony Fauci, advocating for the full reopening of schools and speaking out against lockdown measures.</p><p>His <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/scott-atlas-new-medical-adviser-anti-lockdown-pro-schools-reopening-2020-8\">new hiring has sparked concern in the scientific community</a>, as more than 100 of Atlas' former colleagues at <a href=\"https://www.mercurynews.com/2020/09/12/stanford-doctors-take-aim-at-former-colleague-scott-atlas-trumps-new-adviser-on-the-covid-19-pandemic/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"347c2f71d89b4484fdef3f26a50d09a3\">Stanford Medical School</a> signed a letter warning that many of his \"opinions and statements run counter to established science.\"</p><p>Billionaire Bill Gates also suggested last month that Atlas was hired because he \"agrees\" with what he described as the White House's \"<a href=\"https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/12702442/bill-gates-trump-fauci-scott-atlas-crackpot-covid/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"ffe8cbd9804a404d46fb19ab76135d37\">crackpot COVID theories</a>.\"&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/scott-atlas-hits-back-critics-questioning-science-fauci-redfield-2020-10\">In an interview with Business Insider earlier this month,</a> the doctor said that he thinks the criticism \"stems from people who are either politically motivated or are interested in maintaining their own stature in the public eye.\"</p><p>\"I'm not here to be an epidemiologist. I'm here because I can translate complicated medical science ... in a way that is plain English and understandable by the public and by the White House,\" he said.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/diy-cloth-face-coverings.html\">According to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) website</a>, face coverings \"help stop the spread of COVID-19 to others.\" It recommends people wear them in public, especially when it is not possible to maintain social distancing.&#160;</p><p>Business Insider has contacted Twitter for comment.</p><ul class=\"read-more-links\"><li>Read more:<section></section></li><li><a href=\"https://www.insider.com/white-house-staff-members-who-had-covid-19-2020-10\" data-read-more-link=\"\" data-e2e-name=\"read-more-link\">These are the members of the White House staff and inner circle who have tested positive for COVID-19 this year</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/white-house-staff-scared-after-trumps-return-with-coronavirus-axios-2020-10\">'It's insane': White House staffers are mad about Trump's diagnosis and terrified now that he's back from the hospital while still infected, reports say</a><br><section></section></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/white-house-virus-outbreak-worst-hit-any-major-government-2020-10\">The COVID-19 outbreak at the White House is the worst to hit any major government</a><br><section></section></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/tweet-removed-dr-scott-atlas-masks-dont-prevent-covid-19-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=q8LXiaTiaW0:x94fr__ID1o:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=q8LXiaTiaW0:x94fr__ID1o:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=q8LXiaTiaW0:x94fr__ID1o:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=q8LXiaTiaW0:x94fr__ID1o:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=q8LXiaTiaW0:x94fr__ID1o:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=q8LXiaTiaW0:x94fr__ID1o:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=q8LXiaTiaW0:x94fr__ID1o:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=q8LXiaTiaW0:x94fr__ID1o:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/q8LXiaTiaW0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 18 Oct 2020 16:44:10 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8c42719e9fe40019009f6a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"f9c8759771183f42178b5b564bd00b16","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn20@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-36-783_b8d932adebee61ce.webp","destWidth":1778,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":122876,"destBytes":122876,"author":"sankel@businessinsider.com (Sophia Ankel)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f8c428ac21cfb0019468a65?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn51@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-25-597_7526028f005cf199.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=q8LXiaTiaW0:x94fr__ID1o:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn16@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-32-461_8b84aec9ac9a9ec1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=q8LXiaTiaW0:x94fr__ID1o:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn32@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-19-144_81cf2029a5ff584d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=q8LXiaTiaW0:x94fr__ID1o:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn32@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-23-655_35ed892ca0f41e9f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/q8LXiaTiaW0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn12@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-23-422_b25ec9b036507230.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520883},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Biden and Harris have awful records. Trump is making it easy for me to vote for them anyway.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-kamala-harris-awful-records-trump-voting-democratic-anyway-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89d3449e9fe40019009cce?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Joe Biden Kamala Harris masks DNC\" height=\"2500\" width=\"5000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Joe Biden and Kamala Harris greet supporters outside the Chase Center in Wilmington, Delaware, at the conclusion of the Democratic National Convention, held virtually amid the novel coronavirus pandemic, on August 20, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/former-vice-president-and-democratic-presidential-nominee-news-photo/1228132294?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">OLIVIER DOULIERY/AFP via Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Joe Biden and Kamala Harris represent much of what I loathe in politicians, particularly the way they've wielded power in the world of criminal justice.&#160;</li>\n<li>Biden is one of the key architects of the failed, immoral War on Drugs, and a supporter of almost every US military intervention of the past half-century.</li>\n<li>Harris, as a district attorney and attorney general, cracked down on poor people and addicts, while turning a blind eye to police and prosecutorial corruption.&#160;</li>\n<li>So why am I voting for these ethically compromised, power-hungry career politicians? It's simple: Donald Trump has been president for almost four years.&#160;</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Joe Biden and Kamala Harris represent, respectively, the go-along-to-get-along stasis of a lifelong politician and the frightening potential for abuse by a cop on a well-meaning crusade.&#160;</p><p>Particularly when it comes to civil liberties and criminal justice reform — umbrella terms for the issues with which I'm most politically engaged — they have <a href=\"https://reason.com/2019/09/12/calling-out-kamala-harris-record-as-a-draconian-prosecutor-isnt-a-distortion/\">absolutely terrible records</a> as overreaching \"tough on crime\" <a href=\"https://neiuindependent.org/16326/opinions/chronicling-joe-bidens-vendetta-against-recreational-drug-use/\">politicians</a>.&#160;</p><p>And yet I'm going to vote for the Democratic ticket anyway — resolutely, though not without some lamentation that it has come to this — because Donald Trump's presidency is that indefensible and destructive.&#160;</p><h2>Voting while holding one's nose&#160;</h2><p>It feels terrible to vote for candidates you dislike or distrust, but we've all got our own political calculus. Mine is centered on an unbending desire to see Trump's political career end in humiliating defeat.&#160;</p><p>An ideal scenario would be voters rendering Trumpism toxic overnight by not only firing him from the presidency, but giving Democrats full control of Congress. Only when Trump proves himself a liability to the party he hijacked can the GOP be reborn as something resembling their supposed ideals, a free market-supporting center-right party that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-trade-war-china-beijing-tariffs-unmitigated-disaster-2020-9\">wouldn't pursue policies like an economically damaging trade war</a>.&#160;</p><p>Not because my political identity is particularly fascinating, but merely for the context of this column, I've taken to calling myself a \"civil libertarian,\" mainly because civil liberties issues are what animate me most.</p><p>At various times I've voted for Libertarian, Republican, and Democratic presidential tickets. I'm atypical in the American electorate — a politically-active registered independent who rejects the duopoly and truly holds no allegiance to either liberal or conservative orthodoxy.&#160;</p><p>Point being, I'm nobody's reliable Democratic voter.&#160;</p><p>And I am not voting for Biden/Harris because I have any hope of them \"<a href=\"https://unitethecountry.com/\">uniting</a>\" the country or \"<a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-11/joe-biden-s-return-to-normalcy-campaign-has-echoes-of-1920\">returning us to normalcy</a>.\" With some of the most prominent voices on the left twisting themselves into pretzels to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stop-making-excuses-protesters-act-like-bad-cops-portland-seattle-2020-9\">justify rioting and looting</a>, and the US' major right-leaning party openly <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-laura-loomer-marjorie-greene-qanon-gop-party-conspiracy-theory-2020-8https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-laura-loomer-marjorie-greene-qanon-gop-party-conspiracy-theory-2020-8\">embracing QAnon conspiracy theorists and bigots</a>, I'm confident this country is politically and culturally broken, and will be for some time.&#160;</p><p>Biden and Harris have my vote despite their deplorable records in government. Those records are a primer on what they could do in the most powerful office in the world. I want them to be kept honest about those records.&#160;</p><h2>Biden made bad laws, Harris enforced laws badly</h2><p>Way back when there were <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/everyone-who-is-running-for-president-in-2020-2019-1\">20-something Democratic presidential candidates</a>, I zeroed-in on Biden and Harris as the two I'd least like to see at the top of the ticket.&#160;</p><p>Biden presented himself as America's folksy, work-across-the-aisle, \"get stuff done\" lawmaker. And boy did he get stuff done.&#160;</p><p>Over four decades as a senator from Delaware, Biden <a href=\"https://theintercept.com/2019/09/17/the-untold-story-joe-biden-pushed-ronald-reagan-to-ramp-up-incarceration-not-the-other-way-around/\">tried to outdo the Reagan-era Republicans</a> in crafting Drug War legislation. He helped create the role of federal \"<a href=\"https://fee.org/articles/joe-biden-the-architect-of-america-s-disastrous-war-on-drugs/\">drug czar</a>.\" He was instrumental in drafting the mass incarceration-exacerbating <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/25/us/joe-biden-crime-laws.html\">1994 Crime Bill</a>. He <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-touted-crime-bill-1992-death-penalty-jaywalking-senate-2019-6\">bragged about introducing legislation</a> that did \"everything but hang people for jaywalking.\"&#160;</p><p>Even in the 2000s he was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-ban-raves-jail-promoters-ecstasy-2001-hearing-2019-6\">the Senate's reliably out-of-touch Democratic narc</a>, pushing to criminalize raves, arrest party promoters, and urging local municipalities to use the \"crack-house legislation\" he co-sponsored in 1986 to bust up parties.</p><p>Most Americans <a href=\"https://www.cato.org/blog/55-americans-favor-decriminalizing-drugs\">now favor the decriminalization of drugs</a> and recognize the damage wrought by mandatory sentencing and mass incarceration.&#160;</p><p>Biden has supported nearly every US military intervention of the past half century (though to his credit, <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/story/2016/06/joe-biden-libya-wrong-224595\">he opposed President Obama's intervention in Libya</a>, which proved disastrous).&#160;</p><p>But Biden can't escape the fact that as chair of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, <a href=\"https://www.jacobinmag.com/2019/07/joe-biden-iraq-war-hawk-presidential-candidate\">he enthusiastically whipped Democratic support</a> for President George W. Bush's invasion of Iraq — unquestionably the US' worst foreign policy fiasco since the Vietnam War.&#160;</p><p>Harris' record isn't nearly as long as Biden's, but that doesn't mean she hasn't notched some dubious feats of her own.&#160;</p><p>Awkwardly selling herself as both a no-nonsense prosecutor and as a woke, hip-hop loving, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kamala-harris-father-condemns-jamaica-marijuana-joke-2019-2\">former pot smoker</a>, Harris' political career cannot be divorced from her work as a self-described \"top cop.\"&#160;</p><p>Though Harris says as a district attorney and California's attorney general she was a \"progressive prosecutor,\" Harris was, in fact, both tough-on-crime and soft-on-bad cops.&#160;</p><p>As Reason's <a href=\"https://reason.com/2019/06/03/kamala-harris-is-a-cop-who-wants-to-be-president/\">Elizabeth Nolan Brown</a> put it:</p><p>\"Every attorney general fights for state power and police prerogatives. It's part of the job. But over and over again, Harris went beyond the call of duty, fighting for harsher sentences, larger bail requirements, longer prison terms, more prosecution of petty crimes, greater criminal justice involvement in low-income and minority communities, less due process for people in the system, less transparency, and less accountability for bad cops.\"</p><p>As San Francisco's DA, Harris' office <a href=\"https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/sfpd-crime-lab-case-from-a-z/1866446/\">turned a blind eye for years</a> to a corrupt police lab technician whose work resulted in hundreds of convictions. She <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2019/jan/31/kamala-harris-laughed-jailing-parents-truancy\">aggressively cracked down </a>on parents of truant kids. She <a href=\"https://www.ocregister.com/2019/09/11/kamala-harriss-criminal-justice-reform-plan-cant-be-trusted/\">pushed to bar addicts</a> with prior convictions for selling drugs from Drug Courts, which allow non-violent drug offenders to avoid jail time if they complete a drug rehabilitation program.&#160;</p><p>The progressive-leaning <a href=\"https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:wYvRiW0ARkkJ:https://prospect.org/justice/how-kamala-harris-fought-to-keep-nonviolent-prisoners-locked-up/+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=ust=clnk&#38;gl=us\">American Prospect</a> wrote that as California attorney general, Harris&#160; \"repeatedly and openly defied US Supreme Court orders to reduce overcrowding in California prisons,\" adding that \"Harris and her legal team filed motions that were condemned by judges and legal experts as obstructionist, bad-faith, and nonsensical, at one point even suggesting that the Supreme Court lacked the jurisdiction to order a reduction in California's prison population.\"</p><p>Also as AG, <a href=\"https://californiainnocenceproject.org/read-their-stories/daniel-larsen/\">Harris' office fought to keep an exonerated man in prison</a> because his lawyers had missed a filing deadline, and only freed him from prison once compelled to do so by the courts. Harris' office tried <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-14/kamala-harris-offices-fought-payments-to-wrongly-convicted\">to keep exonerated former prisoners from collecting financial compensation</a> from the state that wrongfully stole years of their lives. Her office was also known to \"<a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2019/08/kamala-cop-record/596758/\">slow roll</a>\" investigations into corrupt or abusive cops and prosecutors.&#160;</p><p>So why am I voting for these ethically compromised, power-hungry career politicians?&#160;</p><p>It's simple: Donald Trump has been president for almost four years.&#160;</p><h2>Look around, this mess is Trump's legacy</h2><p>This isn't 2016 anymore, where we can play \"wouldn't it be nice\" imagination games about how a brash political outsider could shake up the system and rise to the occasion.&#160;</p><p>Much of what was feared about a Trump presidency has come to bear.&#160;</p><p>On his watch, the GOP has decisively abandoned <a href=\"https://www.newyorker.com/news/our-columnists/donald-trump-and-the-gop-confirm-their-fiscal-conservatism-was-a-sham\">fiscal conservatism</a> and sat idly while he personally dismantled the alliances that preserved the US-led <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/09/28/donald-trump-unga-liberal-world-order-220738\">post-World War II international order</a>. He has <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-supporters-chant-send-her-back-president-attacks-ilhan-omar-2019-7\">normalized casual racism</a> and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-broke-brains-conspiracy-theories-obamagate-vote-mail-coronavirus-2020-5\">baseless conspiracy theory-mongering</a>. He has presided over <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/totally-under-control-filmmaker-alex-gibney-trumps-coronavirus-response-2020-10\">the worst national coronavirus response</a> in the developed world, resulting in the deaths of nearly 220,000 Americans.&#160;</p><p>Politics aside, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/former-trump-officials-incompetent-liars-bolton-kelly-mattis-cohn-2020-9\">he's a terrible executive</a>. Trump <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-crazy-stupid-distraction-racism-conspiracy-theories-voters-2020-8\">continues to fail</a> our country by every meaningful metric.&#160;</p><p>As for his boasts of being a great <a href=\"https://www.npr.org/2020/10/16/921662530/trumps-and-biden-s-plans-for-criminal-justice\">criminal justice reformer</a>, Trump deserves credit for championing prison reform by signing the First Step Act. However, Trump's Justice Department is <a href=\"https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/research-reports/what-first-step-act-and-whats-happening-it\">chipping away at its effectiveness</a>. He also reversed Obama administration policy and <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/02/26/trump-administration-says-that-militarizing-police-reduces-crime-is-that-true/\">rebooted the federal government's program</a> of giving excess military equipment to local police departments. Just this week <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/msnbc/opinion/trump-s-praise-extrajudicial-killings-cancels-out-his-law-order-ncna1243591\">he celebrated</a> an extrajudicial police killing. And Trump's as pro-police union — the most immovable opponents of reform — <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biggest-police-union-fop-endorses-trump-for-president-over-biden-2020-9\">as it gets</a>.&#160;</p><p>That said, wanting Trump gone by any democratic means necessary doesn't mean the Democrats get a pass.&#160;</p><p>Concerns about the Democratic Party taking a hard left turn on economic and social issues are ones I share. We desperately need to address climate change, but the <a href=\"https://www.factcheck.org/2019/03/how-much-will-the-green-new-deal-cost/\">Green New Deal</a> isn't remotely workable in its current form. The growing left-wing trend of using <a href=\"https://www.npr.org/2020/07/20/892943728/professor-criticizes-book-white-fragility-as-dehumanizing-to-black-people\">racial essentialism</a> to achieve \"justice\" is one I wholeheartedly reject. And I think it's positively nuts for liberals to be <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/dont-make-social-media-tech-bro-twitter-facebook-arbiters-truth-2020-5\">calling for billionaire tech bros to be the arbiters of truth</a> online.&#160;</p><p>With hope, I'll be throwing rhetorical rocks at a Biden administration come January 20 and for four years thereafter. (And yes, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-new-hampshire-crash-burn-shows-time-end-campaign-2020-2\">I was an idiot</a> to declare Biden's candidacy dead after he wiped out in Iowa and New Hampshire.)</p><p>Whatever objections I might have to a Biden administration's policies, I have faith that it would competently manage the machinery of government, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/totally-under-control-filmmaker-alex-gibney-trumps-coronavirus-response-2020-10\">rather than hollow it out</a> and replace it with nothing, <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/politics/government-hollowed-out-weaknesses/\">as Trump did</a>.&#160;&#160;</p><p>I've never felt worse about voting for a presidential ticket, but I'm doing it this year, unapologetically and enthusiastically. My hands would probably be shaking as I shade in the ovals on the ballot, if pandemic-life hadn't robbed me of the ability to feel emotion.&#160;</p><p>And yet I'm completely resolved in my decision to vote for the Democrats, simply because Trump and Trumpism must be repudiated by the greatest number of Americans as possible in the clearest of terms. For me in 2020, a third party protest vote just isn't as loud as a Democratic protest vote.&#160;</p><p>The Republicans can thank Donald Trump for my 2020 Democratic vote.&#160;</p><ul class=\"read-more-links\"><li>Read more:</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/republicans-sense-trump-train-finally-gone-off-rails-2020-10\" data-analytics-position=\"1\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Republicans sense the Trump train has finally gone off the rails, and they're tiptoeing toward the exits</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/totally-under-control-filmmaker-alex-gibney-trumps-coronavirus-response-2020-10\" data-analytics-position=\"2\" data-analytics-module=\"\">'Totally Under Control' filmmaker Alex Gibney on Trump's hapless coronavirus response, Jared Kushner's ridiculous PPE strategy, and the breakdown of America's institutions</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/andrew-cuomo-memory-hole-covid-nursing-home-coronavirus-new-york-2020-10\" data-analytics-position=\"8\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Andrew Cuomo is shamelessly trying to memory-hole his coronavirus nursing home fiasco</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/35-years-pmrc-rock-lyrics-senate-tipper-gore-frank-zappa-2020-9\" data-analytics-position=\"15\" data-analytics-module=\"\">35 years ago the Senate held hearings on rock lyrics. It was a First Amendment showdown for the ages.</a></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-kamala-harris-awful-records-trump-voting-democratic-anyway-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=S6dmVodY1PA:J2z3LT5c-k4:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=S6dmVodY1PA:J2z3LT5c-k4:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S6dmVodY1PA:J2z3LT5c-k4:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=S6dmVodY1PA:J2z3LT5c-k4:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S6dmVodY1PA:J2z3LT5c-k4:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=S6dmVodY1PA:J2z3LT5c-k4:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=S6dmVodY1PA:J2z3LT5c-k4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S6dmVodY1PA:J2z3LT5c-k4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/S6dmVodY1PA\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 18 Oct 2020 11:53:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f89d417d260780019341e01?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"3fece0023c22ea8c418e2522a24c13c2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn15@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-36-743_9c258fcab8e3c7ae.webp","destWidth":4539,"destHeight":3404,"sourceBytes":651764,"destBytes":651764,"author":"afisher@businessinsider.com (Anthony L. Fisher)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f89d3449e9fe40019009cce?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn51@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-30-074_4cc4b2b931aa2a6c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S6dmVodY1PA:J2z3LT5c-k4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn19@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-21-174_06bc9732fee71af9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S6dmVodY1PA:J2z3LT5c-k4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-25-729_0ea3587fe3e46814.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S6dmVodY1PA:J2z3LT5c-k4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn84@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-36-614_d2af0b0cadf920d9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/S6dmVodY1PA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn75@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-32-152_bbd87b119e10aa6f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520945},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Boris Johnson's government has given the police stronger powers to access people's contact details and check if they are self-isolating under tougher coronavirus rules","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-uk-police-have-new-power-to-check-if-people-self-isolate-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8c02fe9e9fe40019009f5b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Matt Hancock\" height=\"600\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>UK Health Secretary Matt Hancock.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Henry Nicholls</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Police officers in the UK now have the power to check if people are self-isolating when told to do so.</li>\n<li>Boris Johnson's government has agreed to give police more robust powers to crack down on people who fail or refuse to self-isolate after catching the coronavirus or are close contacts of those with the virus.</li>\n<li>Police will be given access to details of individuals on a \"case-by-case basis.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The UK police will have the power to check on individuals who have been told to self-isolate as Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government tries to crack down on people flouting coronavirus law.</p><p>The UK government's Department of Health and Social Care has agreed to provide the National Police Chiefs Council with information on individuals who have been told to isolate on a \"case-by-case basis,\" <a href=\"https://news.sky.com/story/coronavirus-police-granted-access-to-details-of-people-told-to-self-isolate-by-test-and-trace-12106988\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Sky News reports.</a></p><p>People in the UK who test positive for the coronavirus are required by law to self-isolate for 10 days after first displaying symptoms, or for 10 days after getting their result if they are asymptomatic. Members of their household are required to self-isolate for two weeks.</p><p>Johnson's government has given the police the power to check to see if individuals are self-isolating in a bid to deter people from ignoring instructions enshrined in law. They will have access to the names, addresses, and contact details of individuals who do not comply with the requirement to self-isolate.</p><p>A spokesperson for the department told Sky News: \"It is a legal requirement for people who have tested positive for COVID-19 and their close contacts to self-isolate when formally notified to do so.</p><p>\"The DHSC has agreed a memorandum of understanding with the NPCC to enable police forces to have access on a case-by-case basis to information that enables them to know if a specific individual has been notified to self-isolate.</p><p>\"The memorandum of understanding ensures that information is shared with appropriate safeguards and in accordance with the law. No testing or health data is shared in this process.\"</p><p>A spokesperson for the National Police Chiefs Council told Sky News that officers would \"engage with individuals to establish their circumstances, using their discretion wherever it is reasonable to do so.\"</p><p>With the UK descending into a second wave of the coronavirus, there are concerns that the contact tracing system developed by the UK government to contain the spread of the virus is not reaching enough people to be effective.</p><p>The National Health Service Test &#38; Trace <a href=\"https://www.itv.com/news/2020-10-15/covid-nhs-test-and-trace-records-worst-weekly-performance-despite-local-councils-efforts-in-reaching-contacts\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">this week</a> recorded its worst-ever performance in tracking people who had been in contact with someone with the virus, according to new data.</p><p>The system reached just 62.6% of people who had been in close contact with people who had tested positive for the virus in the week ending October 7.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-uk-police-have-new-power-to-check-if-people-self-isolate-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2020 14:36:31 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8c02689e9fe40019009f5a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"d6c2a57dd646d888e4121d5494e7b95d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn91@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-37-433_511786ec4b8e345d.webp","destWidth":1332,"destHeight":999,"sourceBytes":53102,"destBytes":53102,"author":"apayne@businessinsider.com (Adam Payne)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f8c02fe9e9fe40019009f5b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn23@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-26-297_eb3a23a207772490.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=dK6TGpQ_IfI:pIl_nICSP-A:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn11@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-21-150_4ae17a549a99d0fc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=dK6TGpQ_IfI:pIl_nICSP-A:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn71@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-26-721_813e45824b0cccca.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=dK6TGpQ_IfI:pIl_nICSP-A:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn4@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-35-076_d0c6df554748758f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/dK6TGpQ_IfI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn88@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-34-744_c550531427911699.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520941},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Boeing 737 Max, the plane that's been grounded since 2019 after two crashes killed 346 people, is safe to fly again, according to Europe's aviation regulator","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/boeing-737-max-safe-to-fly-european-avaition-regulator-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f0dcfda4dca687b8e0d63e7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: Grounded Boeing 737 MAX aircraft are seen parked in an aerial photo at Boeing Field in Seattle, Washington, U.S. July 1, 2019.  REUTERS/Lindsey Wasson\" height=\"3410\" width=\"4951\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Boeing&#39;s 737 Max planes have been grounded since March 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Europe's aviation regulator says that Boeing's 737 Max is safe to return to the skies. The FAA, which is Boeing's main regulator, has not committed to a date that the 737 Max will be able to fly again.</li>\n<li>And American Airlines just announced plans to fly 737 Max planes between Miami and New York starting December 29th.</li>\n<li>The 737 Max was grounded in March of 2019, following two crashes that resulted in the death of 346 people.&#160;Authorities around the world, including the FAA, have been reviewing the 737 Max's design and safety features.&#160;</li>\n<li>Boeing completed its first recertification test flight in June this year.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Boeing's 737 Max, an update to the 737 first announced in 2011, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/boeing-737-max-timeline-history-full-details-2019-9\">has been grounded since March 2019</a>. Two crashes, during which pilots struggled to control the plane, resulted in the death of a combined 346 people and led to questions about the plane's design and features.</p><p>Since grounding the plane, Boeing has been working on a complete redesign of the plane's flight software.</p><p>On Friday, Patrick Ky, executive director of the European Union Aviation Safety Agency, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-16/boeing-max-declared-safe-to-fly-by-europe-s-aviation-regulator\">told Bloomberg</a> that he's satisfied with the changes Boeing has made to the aircraft. Ky added that the 737 Max could begin flying in Europe before the end of 2020.&#160;</p><p>American Airlines announced on Sunday plans to fly 737 Max planes between Miami and New York from December 29th through January 4th. The airline said it's taking a \"phased approach,\" and has not confirmed whether it will continue using the aircraft beyond that period. American Airlines' plans are contingent on a green light from the Federal Aviation Administration, which hasn't yet committed to a timeline for approval of the 737 Max.</p><p>Touted as a more fuel-efficient version of the 737 consumer plane, the 737 Max is said to have a longer range, lower operating cost, and enough in common with previous models that pilots could switch back and forth between the two seamlessly.&#160;</p><p>The crashes called into question Boeing's training practices, as well. During the aircraft's rollout, pilots were only required to take a brief tablet-based course, rather than training in a simulator like they would for a new plane.</p><p>A so-called synthetic sensor, a software update demanded by the EASA in 2019, still hasn't been implemented by Boeing, and isn't expected to be ready for another two years. But the EASA says that the plane currently meets safety standards, and the \"third sensor\" would meet even higher safety levels.</p><p>The FAA is Boeing's main regulator, and under international law, the 737 Max won't be able to fly until the FAA allows it. In June, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/boeing-737-max-first-certification-test-flight-faa-jet-2020-6\">Boeing completed its first recertification flight test</a>, one of many steps required before the plane can return to service.</p><h1>There are several ongoing federal investigations and lawsuits&#160;</h1><p>There are several federal investigations underway, looking into the design of the jet as part of an effort to determine how it was allowed to be certified in the first place and whether there was criminal negligence behind the design. The fallout from the crashes ultimately cost then-CEO Dennis Muilenburg his job.</p><p>Meanwhile, Boeing is currently seeking to settle cases brought by the families of those killed in the second of the two fatal crashes. An Ethiopian Airlines plane crashed into the ground in March 2019, killing all 157 people on board.</p><p>Boeing has largely settled cases from the earlier October 2018 crash of a 737 Max operated by Indonesia's Lion Air, where 189 people died.&#160;</p><p>But the cases brought in relation to the Ethiopian Airlines crash, Boeing is taking a \"scorched earth\" approach, a contrast to the Lion Air cases, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/boeing-evidence-737-max-ethiopian-cases-lawyer-2020-10\">Business Insider has reported</a>.&#160;</p><p>One lawyer involved in the case says that Boeing's lawyers were refusing to provide evidence that the victims' representatives requested. Boeing says that it had taken its obligations to provide evidence \"seriously.\"&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Elon Musk's SpaceX keeps winning US military contracts — here's why, according to an aerospace expert","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-spacex-military-contracts-dod-space-force-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ec6dcfd3f7370691e747130?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Elon Musk SpaceX\" height=\"1996\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>SpaceX founder and chief engineer Elon Musk.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Steve Nesius</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The US military's increasing need for fast transport explains why it keeps handing contracts to SpaceX, according to a leading aerospace expert.</li>\n<li>Steve Nutt, professor in aerospace engineering, told Business Insider that SpaceX is the US' best alternative to \"stodgy, slow\" traditional contractors.</li>\n<li>it comes at a time when the Department of Defense is \"retooling\" in light of growing global political tension, Nutt said.</li>\n<li>\"The rockets that SpaceX has been asked to supply would address that need &#8212; delivering hardware and support supplies rapidly to anywhere in the world,\" Nutt said.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Elon Musk's SpaceX has secured <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/musks-spacex-partners-us-military-to-deliver-weapons-by-rockets-2020-10\">three military contracts</a> in as many months — and one aerospace expert believes the deals won't end there.</p><p>The US Department of Defense (DoD) increasingly wants to transport supplies faster, according to Steve Nutt, professor of aerospace and mechanical engineering at the University of Southern California.</p><p>SpaceX can fulfill that need at a time when the US military is \"retooling\" because of growing global political tensions, Nutt told Business Insider.</p><p>\"The rockets that SpaceX has been asked to supply would address that need — delivering hardware and support supplies rapidly to anywhere in the world,\" Nutt said.</p><p>Traditional contractors have proven to be \"so stodgy, slow, and expensive that SpaceX is the only alternative,\" he said.</p><p>In August, SpaceX won a slice of a billion-dollar agreement to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spacex-wins-space-force-rocket-launch-nssl-agreement-40-percent-2020-8\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"32ba5529edd6e5806f748350e97cd957\">launch new rockets for the Space Force</a>. Two months later, it secured a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musks-spacex-wins-pentagon-missile-tracking-satellite-contract-2020-10\">$149 million Pentagon contract</a>&#160;to make satellites that can track missiles.</p><p>Then, less than a week later, on October 8, the US military <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/musks-spacex-partners-us-military-to-deliver-weapons-by-rockets-2020-10\">said it was teaming up with SpaceX</a> to build a rocket capable of delivering weapons around the world at 7,500 mph.&#160;</p><p>A 7,652-mile journey from Florida to Afghanistan could be completed within about an hour with such a high-speed rocket, per <a href=\"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/musk-rocket-would-go-from-us-to-the-middle-east-in-an-hour-xfznrdg9f\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-ml-dynamic=\"true\" data-ml-dynamic-type=\"sl\" data-orig-url=\"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/musk-rocket-would-go-from-us-to-the-middle-east-in-an-hour-xfznrdg9f\" data-ml-id=\"3\" data-ml=\"true\" data-xid=\"fr1602947405472ice\" data-skimlinks-tracking=\"xid:fr1602947405472ice\" data-uri=\"c9b6b3b56cfceaaa48dc6a025d15a103\">The Times</a>.</p><p>In comparison, a US C-17 Globemaster, a military transport aircraft costing $218 million with a maximum speed of 590 mph, would complete this journey in about 15 hours.</p><p>The DoD's need for speed is increasingly important given rising global political tensions between the US and other countries, such as North Korea, Nutt said.&#160;</p><p>\"The days of heavily armored tanks and lumbering trucks are fading,\" Nutt said, as they are \"too easy to target and destroy.\"&#160;</p><p>The DoD wants to be able \"to deploy forces quickly, preferably without detection,\" said Nutt. It means that, theoretically, the military can quickly get in and out before enemy forces attack, reducing the risk of casualties and damage, he said.</p><p>\"The US military are retooling and adjusting for future conflicts,\" said Nutt, adding: \"Unfortunately, I think we're entering another arms race.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-spacex-military-contracts-dod-space-force-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2020 11:30:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f88817ad2607800193419f2?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"50b89a3a341bab107a65b2d7e9f4de60","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn79@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-37-315_ee07995adf369eaa.webp","destWidth":2657,"destHeight":1992,"sourceBytes":135872,"destBytes":135872,"author":"insider@insider.com (Kate Duffy)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5ec6dcfd3f7370691e747130?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn63@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-21-800_55499b75ff7f59be.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0Ay7ywrn1xk:WFqIoNNw1xo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn96@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-24-013_44d9de812b247cde.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0Ay7ywrn1xk:WFqIoNNw1xo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn64@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-16-922_22c223d8792d7b32.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0Ay7ywrn1xk:WFqIoNNw1xo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn19@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-34-425_855c6a7d340016f1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/0Ay7ywrn1xk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-32-954_217ca20323525e63.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520925},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Pete Buttigieg says his 'marriage might depend on what is about to happen' in Amy Coney Barrett's SCOTUS confirmation","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/buttigieg-says-his-marriage-might-depend-on-scotus-outcome-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8c618a9e9fe40019009f7e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pete buttigieg\" height=\"889\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Democratic presidential candidate South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg speaks during a campaign rally, Sunday, Dec. 22, 2019, in Indianola, Iowa.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Associated Press/Charlie Neibergall</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Former Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg warned of the stakes of Judge Amy Coney Barrett's potential confirmation to the Supreme Court in an interview <a href=\"https://video.foxnews.com/v/6202160457001#sp=show-clips\">on \"Fox News Sunday.\"</a></li>\n<li>\"My marriage might depend on what is about to happen in the senate with regard to this justice,\" he said.&#160;</li>\n<li>Buttigieg doubled down on Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden's criticisms of Barrett's nomination, saying Sunday that the process was \"wrong.\"&#160;</li>\n<li>He also urged the US to \"turn the page\" from President Donald Trump, who he described as a \"destabilizing force\" and a \"president who is incapable\" of handling the novel coronavirus pandemic.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Former Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg warned of the high stakes surrounding Judge Amy Coney Barrett's potential confirmation to the Supreme Court, including the marriage of LGBTQ couples.</p><p>In an interview <a href=\"https://video.foxnews.com/v/6202160457001#sp=show-clips\">on \"Fox News Sunday,\"</a> host Chris Wallace asked Buttigieg about Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden's views on court-packing, the act of adding more justices to shift the ideological balance.&#160;</p><p>The former vice president said most recently on an <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ABC?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1316910688116289537%7Ctwgr%5Eshare_3%2Ccontainerclick_1&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.businessinsider.com%2Fjoe-biden-court-packing-position-not-a-fan-town-hall-2020-100-10\">ABC News town hall</a> held this past week that \"he is not a fan\" of court-packing but <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-court-packing-position-not-a-fan-town-hall-2020-10\">will state his position before Election Day</a>, depending on the confirmation process for Barrett.</p><p>Buttigieg on Sunday <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/inside-pete-buttigieg-s-plan-overhaul-supreme-court-n1012491\">said his views supporting the expanding of the court</a> \"haven't changed,\" and pointed to the policies at play in Barrett's potential confirmation by the Senate.&#160;</p><p>\"We don't want to allow this president to change the subject, which is what they are always doing,\" Buttigieg told Wallace. \"There are all kinds of interesting questions on the future of the American judiciary, but right now as we speak the pre-existing condition coverage of millions of Americans might depend on what is about to happen in the senate with regard to this justice.\"</p><p>\"My marriage might depend on what is about to happen in the senate with regard to this justice,\" Buttigieg added.</p><p>In the confirmation hearing, Barrett <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amy-coney-barrett-scotus-precedents-legalizing-birth-control-lgbtq-relationships-2020-10\">refused to comment on the Supreme Court's landmark rulings </a>protecting LGBTQ rights and the legalization of birth control because she \"can't grade precedent.\" She also <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amy-coney-barrett-apologizes-sexual-preference-lgbtq-scotus-2020-10\">recently apologized</a> for using the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amy-coney-barrett-says-being-lgbtq-is-a-sexual-preference-2020-10\">term \"sexual preference\"</a> when referring to LGBTQ Americans' sexual orientation during her hearing.</p><p>Wallace also asked Buttigieg about his previous criticism of Biden's vote supporting the Iraq war. Last year during the Democratic race for the presidential nomination, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/buttigieg-critiques-bidens-judgment-on-iraq-war-vote-2019-12\">Buttigieg slammed</a> then-fellow candidate Biden's vote as \"an example of why years in Washington is not always the same thing as judgment.\" <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-opposed-iraq-war-didnt-say-until-2005-2019-9\">Biden has since walked back</a>&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2002/10/11/us/threats-responses-vote-congress-authorizes-bush-use-force-against-iraq-creating.html\">his vote</a> and <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2003/ALLPOLITICS/07/30/cnna.irq.biden/\">previous stance</a> that supported use of military force against Iraq, which sparked severe<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-bidens-iraq-war-vote-is-coming-back-to-bite-him-with-2020-voters-2019-5\"> criticism. </a></p><p>Buttigieg doubled down on his belief that invading Iraq was \"a mistake\" but added, \"we are not going to take lessons on Iraq policy from this current president who can barely keep straight what's going on in the Middle East and is a destabilizing force everywhere he goes.\"</p><p>He added that \"we need to turn the page\" from a \"president who is incapable of handling a public health crisis that has now cost almost a quarter of a million American lives, thrown our economy into a total wreckage, and clearly has no plan to do anything about it.\"</p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><script type=\"text/javascript\" src=\"https://video.foxnews.com/v/embed.js?id=6202160457001&w=466&h=263\"></script><noscript>Watch the latest video at <a href=\"https://www.foxnews.com\">foxnews.com</a></noscript></div><div src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VXubrHEH21M:gUARPeuSGeA:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=VXubrHEH21M:gUARPeuSGeA:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VXubrHEH21M:gUARPeuSGeA:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=VXubrHEH21M:gUARPeuSGeA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VXubrHEH21M:gUARPeuSGeA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/VXubrHEH21M\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 18 Oct 2020 16:15:07 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8c618a9e9fe40019009f7e?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"f10f587bab1f633878d6018a9b555248","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn11@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-12-318_ec32a2b87e18e8bf.webp","destWidth":1778,"destHeight":889,"sourceBytes":36058,"destBytes":36058,"author":"ichoi@businessinsider.com (Inyoung Choi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f8c618a9e9fe40019009f7e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn11@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-12-318_ec32a2b87e18e8bf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VXubrHEH21M:gUARPeuSGeA:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn84@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-29-489_3df490b53e05502c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VXubrHEH21M:gUARPeuSGeA:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn71@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-31-211_e8b676327d021e9f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VXubrHEH21M:gUARPeuSGeA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn32@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-29-107_4e5f814b68264f34.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/VXubrHEH21M":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn47@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-29-193_1c3dd5e2f69bf06e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520921},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"The Arctic is on track to lose more ice this century than at any point since the end of the Ice Age. Photos show the dramatic melting.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/photos-reveal-extent-of-arctic-ice-loss-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ef3993b1918241590577b77?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: Chunks of ice float inside of meltwater pools on top of the Helheim glacier near Tasiilaq, Greenland, June 19, 2018.  REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo\" height=\"3648\" width=\"5472\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Chunks of ice float in melt-water pools on top of the Helheim glacier near Tasiilaq, Greenland, June 19, 2018.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Arctic sea ice reached its second-lowest level on record in September, eclipsed only by 2012's low.</li>\n<li>Greenland is on track to lose more ice this century than at any point since the Ice Age ended about 12,000 years ago.&#160;</li>\n<li>Photographs of Arctic regions reveal how land and sea ice are disappearing.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>It was a devastating summer for the Arctic.&#160;</p><p>In September, sea ice in the Arctic Ocean hit a low of about 1.4 million acres – the second-lowest on record, <a href=\"https://nsidc.org/arcticseaicenews/\">according to data from the National Snow and Ice Data Center.</a> The only time it got lower was in 2012, when ice cover reached over just 1.3 million acres.&#160;</p><p>In the 1980s, ice covered at least 1 million more acres of ocean than it does now. In 1980, its minimum extent was <a href=\"https://www.google.com/search?rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS911US911&ei=cal0X6OlGceGsAXe1rOgBA&q=ice+cover+arctic+1980s&oq=ice+cover+arctic+1980s&gs_&sclient=psy-ab&ved=0ahUKEwjjofvznZHsAhVHA6wKHV7rDEQQ4dUDCA0&uact=5wKHV7rDEQQ4dUDCA0&#38;uact=5\">2.7 million square miles</a>, according to NASA.&#160;</p><p>When it comes to ice on land, the picture is just as dire. Greenland is on track to lose more of its ice sheet this century than any other in the past 12,000 years, according to a recent <a href=\"https://press.nature.com/rate-of-mass-loss-from-the-greenland-ice-sheet-will-exceed-holoc/18354264\">study published in the journal Nature</a>.</p><p>Weather patterns, like <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/climate-scientist-konrad-steffen-dies-after-falling-through-thin-ice-2020-8\">seasonal changes in atmospheric pressure</a>, play a role in fluctuations in ice cover and loss. But climate change has overwhelmingly driven the dramatic increase in melting observed over the last 40 years.</p><p>\"Absolutely we're seeing climate change at work because the warm summers become warmer and the cold winters aren't as cold as they were,\" Mark Serreze, director of the Snow and Ice Data Center, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/warming-shrinks-arctic-ocean-ice-to-2nd-lowest-on-record-2020-9\">told the Associated Press</a>.</p><p>The following 11 images reveal how melting ice has transformed the Arctic region.</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tSea ice at the North and South Poles has shrunk dramatically over the last 30 years.\n\t\n\t<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe frameborder=\"0\" class=\"juxtapose\" width=\"100%\" height=\"450\" src=\"https://cdn.knightlab.com/libs/juxtapose/latest/embed/index.html?uid=2ffd24de-033f-11eb-bf88-a15b6c7adf9a\"></iframe></div><p>Toggle left and right in the image above to see how Arctic sea ice levels around Greenland have changed in spring and fall.</p>\n\tMelting sea ice doesn't contribute to sea-level rise, but it has been linked to increased storminess on the US East Coast and changes in jet-stream patterns.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f74b70074fe5b0018a8e41b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ice melt canada arctic\" height=\"3896\" width=\"6000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Researchers look out from the Finnish icebreaker MSV Nordica as the sun sets in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago on July 21, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\">David Goldman/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The jet stream is driven by differences between low temperatures in the Arctic and higher temperatures farther south.</p><p>\"Because we're warming the Arctic so much faster, that north-south temperature difference is getting smaller, and the jet stream is getting weaker,\" Jennifer Francis, a senior scientist at the <a href=\"https://www.woodwellclimate.org/\">Woodwell Climate Research Center</a>, told <a href=\"https://www.wbur.org/earthwhile/2020/09/14/warming-arctic-weather-q-and-a\">WBUR in Boston</a>.</p><p>A weakening jet stream means slower weather patterns, which could lead events like heat waves to last longer.</p>\n\tChanging weather patterns caused by sea-ice loss may also cause more El Niño storms in the Pacific Ocean.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f74bd3574fe5b0018a8e43f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ice melt1\" height=\"4170\" width=\"6720\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sea ice breaks apart as the Finnish icebreaker MSV Nordica traverses through the Victoria Strait in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, July 21, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\">David Goldman/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Over the past 20 years, the Arctic Ocean has warmed so much that air over the sea's surface forms towers of hot air. These towers travel toward the equator, intensifying the trade winds that lead to El Ni&#241;o storms.&#160;</p>\n\tMelting sea ice affects Arctic animals like polar bears. A 2018 study found that polar bears in the region have been losing weight during late spring and early summer, when they should be packing on pounds to prepare for winter.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f74b96374fe5b0018a8e42b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"polarbear weightloss\" height=\"3264\" width=\"4928\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A polar bear rests on a chunk of sea ice in the Arctic on June 15, 2014.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brian Battaile/USGS via AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Polar bears use sea ice to hunt seals, the high-fat prey they need to survive. As ice melts, bears must swim between smallish chunks, which tires them and puts them at higher risk of hypothermia.&#160;</p>\n\tLand ice is also melting at an unprecedented rate: The two biggest ice sheets on Antarctica and Greenland are losing about 427 billion metric tons of ice per year.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d8b2f072e22af28482044a3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE - This early Friday, Aug. 16, 2019 file photo shows an aerial view of large Icebergs floating as the sun rises near Kulusuk, Greenland. Greenland has been melting faster in the last decade, and this summer, it has seen two of the biggest melts on record since 2012. A special United Nations-affiliated oceans and ice report released on Wednesday, Sept. 24, 2019 projects three feet of rising seas by the end of the century, much fewer fish, weakening ocean currents, even less snow and ice, and nastier hurricanes, caused by climate change. (AP Photo/Felipe Dana)\" height=\"2665\" width=\"4000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Large icebergs float as the sun rises near Kulusuk, Greenland, August 16, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Felipe Dana/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>If the world's greenhouse-gas emissions keep going up as forecasted, Greenland will lose four times more ice this century than it has during any other since the end of the last Ice Age, according to the recent study.</p><p>That loss alone could raise sea levels by nearly 4 inches (10 centimeters) by the end of the century.&#160;</p>\n\tFrom 1941 to 2004, Alaska's Muir Glacier retreated 7 miles while its thickness decreased by 2,625 feet.\n\t\n\t<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe frameborder=\"0\" class=\"juxtapose\" width=\"100%\" height=\"450\" src=\"https://cdn.knightlab.com/libs/juxtapose/latest/embed/index.html?uid=ab6fa1fe-0c9b-11eb-bf88-a15b6c7adf9a\"></iframe></div><p>In 2015, researchers at the University of Alaska <a href=\"https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/2015GL064349\">found that</a> the state had lost 75 billion metric tons of glacier ice from 1994 to 2013.&#160;</p>\n\tGreenland is losing about 234 billion tons of land ice per year.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5f4479e6ff30001d4e889d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Spalte glacier gif n79 greenland ice sheet\" height=\"742\" width=\"742\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A gif shows the disintegration of the Spalte Glacier between 2013 and 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Promice</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The Spalte Glacier, above, split off from its parent glacier in late June; it has <a href=\"https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/147350/spalte-splits\">since crumbled into numerous smaller icebergs,</a> and no longer exists as a distinct glacier.</p>\n\tGreenland's ice melt might even have played a role in the death of climate scientist Konrad Steffen.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f35c0f9e89ebf001f0447a2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"steffenreal.JPG\" height=\"1480\" width=\"2200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dr Konrad Steffen performs maintenance on a weather station 70 kilometers (43 miles) northeast of Ilulissat, Greenland, May 17, 2007.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Bob Strong</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The 68-year-old Swiss scientist, who spent 30 years tracking Greenland's disappearing ice, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/climate-scientist-konrad-steffen-dies-after-falling-through-thin-ice-2020-8\">fell into a deep crevasse</a>&#160;in August after an ice sheet he was studying buckled beneath him.&#160;</p><p>\"Konrad Steffen died trying to warn the world,\" CNN reporter Bill Weir <a href=\"https://twitter.com/BillWeirCNN/status/1293931571469312001\">wrote on Twitter</a>.&#160;</p>\n\tMelting land ice goes into the ocean, where it causes sea levels to rise.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f74b6140ab50d00184ad4f3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"sled dogs\" height=\"2160\" width=\"3840\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sled dogs wade through water ankle-deep on top of a melting ice sheet in northwestern Denmark.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Steffen Olsen/Danish Meteorological Institute</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Unlike sea ice, melting land ice raises sea levels because it adds more water to the ocean.&#160;</p>\n\tGreenland's Helheim Glacier, for instance, is sliding into the sea at a rate of 5 miles per year.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f84782cbab422001979ac78?format=jpeg\" alt=\"helheim 2001\" height=\"868\" width=\"540\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Helheim glacier in Greenland has retreated by 4.7 miles between 1972 and 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jesse Allen/NASA Earth Observatory</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>In the images above, the ice on the left is the Helheim glacier, while the chunky ice on the right is ice that has broken off into smaller icebergs that float in a fjord.</p><p>Between 1972 and 2019, the glacier's margin &#8212; the boundary where its ice is breaking off into the fjord &#8212; retreated about 4.7 miles. Today, the Helheim <a href=\"https://vis.sciencemag.org/greenlands-dying-ice/\">accounts for 4%</a> of Greenland's annual ice loss.</p>\n\tWorldwide, sea levels could rise 10 to 12 feet by 2120 if global emissions continue unabated.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/59a6bcc079bbfdba408b61f1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Hurricane Harvey\" height=\"2463\" width=\"5104\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Interstate 69 is covered by floodwaters from Hurricane Harvey in Humble, Texas, August 29, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP/David J. Phillip</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The prediction comes from a <a href=\"https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/publications/techrpt83_Global_and_Regional_SLR_Scenarios_for_the_US_final.pdf\">2017 report</a> by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. That rise in sea levels could cause major American cities &#8211; including Miami, Florida; New Orleans, Louisiana; and Houston, Texas &#8211; <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/american-cities-disappear-sea-level-rise-2100-2019-3#new-orleans-louisiana-is-already-sinking-1\">to disappear underwater</a>.&#160;</p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/photos-reveal-extent-of-arctic-ice-loss-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
