border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/trj4ac4YIU4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 18 Oct 2020 13:30:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5c40c097dde86711a16af66d?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"a654d8d7b869055952bc192a87e04c5c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn27@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-37-721_98c4cb3353a114c1.webp","destWidth":1721,"destHeight":1290,"sourceBytes":104492,"destBytes":104492,"author":"tmohamed@businessinsider.com (Theron Mohamed)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5dc0989a695b583bcf26ec02?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn44@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-30-016_fe09a3762fbb66de.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=trj4ac4YIU4:Xp4JhUHpNgM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn20@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-22-369_705a6d08875409bc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=trj4ac4YIU4:Xp4JhUHpNgM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn15@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-23-464_d761275b8c23a1ae.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=trj4ac4YIU4:Xp4JhUHpNgM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn52@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-16-978_10223bdd9d7ca6ac.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/trj4ac4YIU4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn28@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-29-988_4b6b270afbbae552.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520891},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Twitter botched its own moderation policies by banning a New York Post story and added fuel to the right's baseless belief that Big Tech is waging a war against conservatives","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-happened-twitter-ny-post-biden-moderation-policies-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89d3afd260780019341dfa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"twitter trump\" height=\"1341\" width=\"1788\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Activist Mike Merrigan holds a piñata shaped like the Twitter logo with hair to look like U.S. President Donald Trump during a protest outside of Twitter headquarters on May 28, 2020 in San Francisco, California.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Justin Sullivan/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Twitter earlier this week banned an article published by the New York Post regarding the son of Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden.</li>\n<li>The report was based in part on files and emails that the Post said were taken from Hunter Biden's laptop.</li>\n<li>Twitter's decision to ban a story published by a conservative-leaning publication without explanation seemed to affirm Republicans' long-held theory that Big Tech is biased against the right.</li>\n<li>The move undermined what Twitter has said is its mission to implement fair moderation policies and limit disinformation on its platform, especially ahead of one of the most important presidential elections in modern US history.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Twitter has had a busy week — perhaps even busier than when a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-reels-from-colossal-hack-as-new-details-surface-2020-7\">colossal hack</a> took over the site this past summer.</p><p>On Wednesday, the New York Post, owned by Fox News mogul Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, published a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-york-post-hunter-joe-biden-giuliani-red-flags-disinformation-2020-10\">dubious report</a> purporting to show evidence that Hunter Biden, the son of Democratic presidential hopeful Joe Biden, was in cahoots with a Ukrainian official. You can read a digestible timeline of the erratic series of events spelled out in the article <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fbi-investigating-hunter-biden-burisma-emails-foreign-intelligence-operation-2020-10\">here.</a> (The FBI is now <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fbi-investigating-hunter-biden-burisma-emails-foreign-intelligence-operation-2020-10\">investigating</a> whether the emails were part of a foreign intelligence operation.)&#160;</p><p>Though the story was riddled with holes, Republicans swiftly latched onto it as affirmation of conspiracy theories they've long pedaled involving the Biden family and Ukraine. The publication also faced criticism from some who feared the story was designed to spread disinformation ahead of the 2020 presidential election.&#160;</p><p>As users began to share the story on Twitter, the company responded by banning the URL from being tweeted, therefore limiting how many people could read it, without offering an explanation as to why. The company <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-campaign-account-locked-twitter-ny-post-biden-2020-10\">locked</a> the Trump campaign's official Twitter account, @TeamTrump, after it referred to the NY Post story. White House spokesperson Kayleigh McEnany's account was also suspended.</p><p>Facebook's response to the New York Post article was similar: The company said it would restrict the reach of the article on its platform until a third-party fact-checked its contents. However, the article was still <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-new-york-post-hunter-biden-shared-thousands-after-restrictions-2020-10\">shared nearly 300,000 times</a> on the platform following Facebook's announcement, as Business Insider's Paige Leskin reported.</p><p>It wasn't until later Thursday night that Twitter explained itself, saying that it banned the article for violating its policies around how hacked materials are shared. It's the same reasoning given in June when Twitter <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/blueleaks-twitter-bans-ddosecrets-account-published-secret-police-files-2020-6\">banned a group</a> that released a hoard of police documents that were originally obtained by hackers.&#160;</p><p>Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey has since <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-jack-dorsey-blocking-ny-post-hunter-biden-story-wrong-2020-10\">said</a> it was \"wrong\" to ban the NY Post story. But the damage was already done. GOP Senators now <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/senators-to-subpoena-twitter-ceo-dorsey-after-hunter-biden-articles-2020-10\">plan to subpoena Dorsey</a> to testify regarding the issue, and Republicans have more fodder to feed their long-held, <a href=\"https://mashable.com/article/anti-conservative-bias-facebook/\">often-disproven</a> belief that Big Tech is biased against conservatives.</p><p>The whole debacle is a prime example of the power that tech platforms wield and the potential danger that can result when they make inconsistent decisions in enforcing moderation policies. The incident also comes in the midst of the most important presidential elections in modern US history.</p><p>Twitter did not immediately respond to Business Insider's request for comment.</p><h2>Adding fuel to the partisan fire</h2><p>Social media critics have been calling with greater urgency this year for companies, including Facebook, to make changes that would prevent election interference. Twitter has <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-changes-election-political-misinformation-policy-2020-10\">taken a series of steps</a> to crack down on the spread of misleading content and has been fighting to consistently limit the spread of disinformation through its moderation policies.</p><p>But Twitter didn't quite showcase said cohesive moderation plan with Wednesday's ban.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89edcc9e9fe40019009d98?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jack dorsey twitter\" height=\"1334\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Jack Dorsey, Twitter CEO, and Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook COO, off camera, testify during a Senate (Select) Intelligence Committee hearing in Dirksen Building where they testified on the influence of foreign operations on social media on September 5, 2018\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tom Williams/CQ Roll Call</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>What Twitter did do was add to a growing fire stoked by President Donald Trump and Republicans that Big Tech and its platforms are biased against conservatives, as <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2020/10/twitters-ban-hunter-biden-story-conservative-bias-paranoia/616726/\">The Atlantic's Kaitlyn Tiffany</a> goes into in much greater depth.</p><p>The right has launched a crusade against the tech industry since Twitter began adding <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-twitter-facebook-social-media-war-executive-order-explainer-timeline-2020-5\">fact-check labels</a> in May to President Trump's tweets in which he touted the baseless claims that mail-in voting will lead to a fraudulent election. The platform has also flagged tweets from the president that contained <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-blocked-trump-campaigns-tweets-sharing-false-covid-19-claims-2020-8\">false information about the coronavirus</a>, including a tweet in which <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-labels-trump-tweet-saying-he-has-coronavirus-immunity-as-misleading-2020-10\">Trump falsely claimed immunity</a>.</p><p>During a July congressional hearing — where the leaders of Google, Apple, Facebook, and Amazon were grilled over antitrust concerns — Republican lawmakers made it a point to question the CEOs over anti-conservative bias, a topic that has nothing to do with antitrust laws.</p><p>Twitter and Facebook's crackdown on the New York Post story also prompted the president and other GOP officials to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-york-post-hunter-biden-trump-facebook-twitter-section-230-2020-10\">double down on their call</a> to repeal Section 230, an internet law that shields social media firms from being liable for content posted on their sites. In response, the director of the FCC said he would <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fcc-section-230-reform-trump-puppet-ajit-pai-2020-10\">examine rolling back the protections</a>.</p><p>Following the New York Post incident, Twitter has said it would change its policy regarding the sharing of hacked material. It now will only remove such content if it's shared directly by hackers to the website, not if it is included in a report published by a news publication. But cybersecurity <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-ny-post-hunter-biden-hacked-material-rules-exploitation-2020-10\">experts also told</a> Business Insider's Isobel Asher Hamilton that Twitter's altered policy contains loopholes, ones that could make it easier for hackers to exploit the rules.</p><p>Like Twitter's unprecedented decision to fact-check Trumps' tweets in May, the company's decision to ban the NY Post article — even if it was rooted in good faith to protect the integrity of Twitter's sharing policies — will likely continue to have a ripple effect, especially as the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/doj-asks-congress-to-weaken-section-230-2020-9\">crusade against Section 230</a> continues.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/what-happened-twitter-ny-post-biden-moderation-policies-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2020 12:18:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f89d3afd260780019341dfa?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"c44b7c3b75226f48832d30a0afd7bdaf","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn8@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-15-364_bb42beade0ced6d6.webp","destWidth":1788,"destHeight":1341,"sourceBytes":126148,"destBytes":126148,"author":"insider@insider.com (Katie Canales)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f89d3afd260780019341dfa?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn8@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-15-364_bb42beade0ced6d6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89edcc9e9fe40019009d98?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn48@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-33-670_c1088dd5b2d67552.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=csLPoEQrUgE:ueTgqlRK7mo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn47@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-32-832_3cba030063da8403.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=csLPoEQrUgE:ueTgqlRK7mo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn24@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-18-953_0359dd12b91639fe.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=csLPoEQrUgE:ueTgqlRK7mo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn15@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-24-391_deac98998dc8d89b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/csLPoEQrUgE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn11@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-27-846_71d11a6b25634ce9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520914},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"The Republicans are fundamentally unserious people","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/gop-mcconnell-trump-fundamentally-unserious-people-coronavirus-aid-bill-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89bd6fd260780019341d62?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trump dance campaigning virginia\" height=\"512\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>If it feels like nothing is getting done in America right now, that's because there isn't.</li>\n<li>In large part that is because the Republican Party is made up of unserious people, only interested in perpetuating their own power.</li>\n<li>The President cannot be taken seriously when he says he wants to make a deal &#8212; any kind of deal. The DOJ cannot be taken seriously when it says it is doing an investigation. And Senate Republicans cannot be serious about coronavirus aid negotiations.</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>It's hard for the government to get anything done in this critical moment in American history, and the reason for the disastrous gridlock is simple: Republicans are fundamentally unserious people.</p><p>There's a pandemic raging, <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-business-jobless-claims-united-states-economy-f904abdb3bc24f01e757915eb01a377a\">898,000 Americans</a> filed for unemployment benefits just last week, and the stock market is convulsing because Washington can't pass an economic stimulus bill. The Democrats passed a more than $3 trillion plan in the House in June, while Senate Republicans have argued since this summer that we don't need a large scale bill.</p><p>And no matter what the headlines claim about back and forth between the White House and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the Senate GOP's position hasn't changed either — and that's all that matters. Senate Leader Mitch McConnell has said he will spend no more than $500 billion on a \"targeted\" (some may say \"paltry and inadequate\") stimulus bill to combat the pandemic, and he plans to bring such a doomed bill to the floor of the Senate.</p><p>If it feels like there's some action on this front, it's only because the Trump White House is negotiating with House Speaker Pelosi like a pig on LSD. Trump has said he wants an even bigger bill than the one House Democrats passed. Of course, such a bill does not exist, he hasn't done much to whip votes for such a bill with fellow Republicans, and since the president is lagging in the polls he has little leverage over McConnell.</p><p>Talking to the White House is a waste unless it can move McConnell (unlikely). And McConnell's bill likely won't <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-package-mcconnell-senate-supreme-court-confirmation-2020-10\">provide aid to hurting state and local governments</a>, so it's a no-go with Democrats. These are not serious negotiations, because the Republicans are not serious about this issue — or really anything else.</p><p>The only thing Republicans <em>seem</em> serious about doing is appointing judges, not just in the Supreme Court — where some polls show their rush confirmation of Judge Amy Coney Barrett has met <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-ginsburg-poll/majority-of-americans-including-many-republicans-say-wait-for-election-to-replace-ginsburg-reuters-poll-idUSKCN26B0TN\">widespread disapproval from Americans</a> — but in courts all over the country.</p><p>That is because appointing judges and creating a conservative judicial system perpetuates their power. So Republicans are working fast, appointing more <a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2020/07/15/how-trump-compares-with-other-recent-presidents-in-appointing-federal-judges/\">judges to appeals courts</a> than any president since Carter. But even there, the GOP is not taking things that seriously — making the power grab obvious. Trump has also <a href=\"https://ballotpedia.org/ABA_ratings_during_the_Trump_administration\">nominated more judges rated \"not qualified\"</a> by The American Bar Association (ABA) to the bench than any President since 1989 (when the ABA started keeping track).</p><p>Aside from all that, you won't see Republicans get much done aside from cutting taxes. The GOP is a party without a plan or a platform (at this year's RNC it presented one thing as its platform — Donald Trump.) It has no ideas, no vision for the future of America, no policy proposals, no ambitions beyond maintaing power for itself and those who support it. That is why it is more than useless at a time when we desperately need to get things done, it's dangerous. This Republican Party will put its own aspirations for power ahead of the public good.</p><p>The GOP's shallowness extends beyond the pandemic to issues it used to champion. Think Republicans are serious about the rule of law? Just this week the Department of Justice was forced to admit that an investigation into whether or not Obama administration spied on the Trump campaign gleaned nothing. Trump had been crowing that Attorney General Bill Barr would announce something as an October Surprise for the Trump campaign. But lo, here is October and the evidence has not materialized.</p><p>How about national security? The Washington Post reports that Barr and others in the Trump administration have <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/giuliani-biden-ukraine-russian-disinformation/2020/10/15/43158900-0ef5-11eb-b1e8-16b59b92b36d_story.html\">known that Rudy Giuliani</a> was involved in a Russian intelligence operation, feeding misinformation to the President. They aren't serious people, though, so they didn't do anything about it.</p><p>Republicans don't have a plan to replace Obamacare or an idea of how to keep people with preexisting conditions covered if the Supreme Court agrees with the Trump administration and strikes down the law,&#160;because they are not serious.</p><p>Republicans do not have a plan to distribute a coronavirus vaccine when it shows up because they are not serious. And we don't know the truth about the president's health right now because Republicans are not serious.</p><p>Now, perhaps you think that Pelosi should just come to some kind of deal with the White House, and see if Trump will take time off from ranting on Twitter and calling in to Fox News to whip the votes for an aid bill that could pass the House. In a normal administration this might be the right course of action. But Trump's administration and his Republicans are not normal. People who try to act like they are normal get burned.</p><p>Just ask US Trade Representative and China hardliner Robert Lighthizer. He led negotiations for the US-China Phase Once trade deal, and he is now trying to <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/06/business/economy/china-robert-lighthizer.html\">save the deal</a> from forces within the Trump administration that want to kill the deal <em>they themselves</em> negotiated less than a year ago. He thought that White House really wanted to get something done on the US-China economic front — his mistake.</p><p>This is what you get when you try do serious things with fundamentally unserious people.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/gop-mcconnell-trump-fundamentally-unserious-people-coronavirus-aid-bill-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=NnAB7fAJgc4:Sz9OE0o38EA:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"I visited a COVID-19-themed boutique selling high-priced 'essentials' to wealthy shoppers in high-end malls alongside Hermes and Louis Vuitton stores – see inside","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/covid-19-essentials-boutique-store-high-priced-face-masks-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8898ac9e9fe4001900994c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1619\" width=\"2158\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>COVID-19 Essentials is a chain of eight stores that sell high-end gadgets and accessories aimed at surviving the pandemic is convenience, luxury, and style.&#160;&#160;</li>\n<li>We visited its Short Hills, New Jersey location, and found a popular store filled with themed masks, metal door openers, and mask pouches.&#160;</li>\n<li>Shoppers seeking Clorox wipes and disposable surgical masks need not enter as they won't find them here.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>COVID-19 Essentials is one of the newest additions to The Mall at Short Hills, a high-end shopping mall near Morristown, New Jersey.</p><p>A short drive from New York City and mere feet from the highway, the suburban mall boasts nearly 200 stores with brands such as Neiman Marcus, Jimmy Choo, and Gucci, just to name a few. Peloton and Tesla even have storefronts here.</p><p>And while regular shoppers might be accustomed to seeing the thousand-dollar handbags of Louis Vuitton or red-bottomed shoes of Christian Louboutin, COVID-19 Essentials is undoubtedly an eye-catcher amidst a sea of luxury. Still geared towards the wealthy, the eight-store chain, according to the <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/11/business/covid-essentials.html\">New York Times</a>, markets the so-called essentials for surviving the pandemic beyond the standard face masks and hand sanitizer.&#160;</p><p>The high price tags that some of the items wear would probably turn the average shopper away at a mall in Middle America but its popularity in Short Hills and elsewhere shows that the rich are living through the pandemic a little differently.</p><p>Take a look inside COVID-19 Essentials.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tThe Mall at Short Hills is New Jersey's self-proclaimed \"premier shopping destination\" with no shortage of high-end retailers.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img an option for $15.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f888207d260780019341a00?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tHere's the workstation where it's done.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8882059e9fe400190098ea?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThere's also a clearance wall where masks are slightly cheaper.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f888206d2607800193419fd?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThree center tables are then dedicated to COVID-19-related gadgets and accessories.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f888208d260780019341a01?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThis handheld device is a UV wand that claims to cleanse surfaces of viruses.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8881fc9e9fe400190098e4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tA larger version claims to disinfect items such as masks or a cell phone.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f888206d2607800193419fc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tPerhaps the most interesting, yet basic devices, are these metal door openers.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f888202d2607800193419f6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBasically a stylus for your hand, the device goes around the user's finger. The tip can be used to press buttons while a hook can be used to grab handles and open doors.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f889198d260780019341a40?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1113\" width=\"1484\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tPlastic inserts are also sold that help keep masks from ruining makeup.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f888202d2607800193419f7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tMask accessories then line the other side of the table, including lanyards that can be attached to the mask for when they're not being used.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f88820cd260780019341a09?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tInstead of putting masks down on a table, the lanyard holds them around the wearer's neck.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f88a324d260780019341ae0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1023\" width=\"1365\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAs an alternative, these pouches can be used to store masks when they're not being used.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8882099e9fe400190098f3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe store also sells the solution to the problem of smelly masks in form of non-toxic mask spray.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f88820cd260780019341a08?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAnd, of course, hand sanitizer is also available for purchase.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8882099e9fe400190098f4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID-19 Essentials The Mall at Short Hills\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The COVID-19 Essentials store at The Mall at Short Hills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=e39HtOsllHM:dvp_v5-aM1A:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn79@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-29-431_7479ea70fd8214df.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=e39HtOsllHM:dvp_v5-aM1A:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn8@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-27-065_3f186f6795d88645.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=e39HtOsllHM:dvp_v5-aM1A:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn4@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-28-753_fee2828f425508f8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/e39HtOsllHM":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn7@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-20-456_e8826c442694874f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520940},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Republican National Committee chair says QAnon is 'something the voters are not even thinking about'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/rnc-chair-qanon-is-something-voters-are-not-thinking-about-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ec2d4523f73707ee5050b03?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Ronna Romney McDaniel, the chair of the Republican National Committee, speaks during the RNC winter meeting at the Trump National Doral Resort in Miami, Friday, Jan. 24, 2020. (Matias J. Ocner/Miami Herald via AP)\" height=\"1097\" width=\"1646\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ronna Romney McDaniel, the chair of the Republican National Committee, speaks during the RNC winter meeting at the Trump National Doral Resort in Miami, Friday, Jan. 24, 2020. (Matias J. Ocner/Miami Herald via AP)\n<p class=\"copyright\">Associated Press</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Republican National Committee Chair Ronna McDaniel dismissed the QAnon movement Sunday, saying the \"fringe group\" isn't an issue Americans are familiar with and don't care about.&#160;</li>\n<li>In a recent poll, most voters who said they were familiar with QAnon characterized the movement as \"very bad\" for the country.</li>\n<li>When asked if she'd condemn the group, McDaniel said, \"It's a fringe group. It's not part of our party.\"</li>\n<li>There is a growing list of&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-qanon-infiltrated-the-gop-2020-10\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"ca3c0c9a337fa028ba8f30b846926429\">Republican politicians who have either backed or avoided denouncing QAnon.</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Ronna McDaniel, the chair of the Republican National Committee, dismissed the QAnon movement Sunday, saying it's an issue Americans aren't familiar with and don't care about.&#160;</p><p>QAnon is a baseless far-right conspiracy theory that claims President Donald Trump is secretly fighting a \"deep state\" cabal of satanic pedophiles and cannibals.</p><p>\"It's something the voters are not even thinking about,\" McDaniel said on ABC News' \"This Week\" Sunday, when asked if she'd condemn QAnon.</p><p>\"It's a fringe group,\" she added. \"It's not part of our party. The vice president said, 'I dismiss it out of hand.' The president said, 'You know what, I don't know anything about this group.'\"</p><p>\"But of course you're going to ask me about that,\" McDaniel said to \"This Week\" host George Stephanopoulos. \"Because it has absolutely nothing to do with this election. Antifa is burning down cities right now.\"</p><p>Last year, the FBI designated&#160;<a href=\"https://news.yahoo.com/fbi-documents-conspiracy-theories-terrorism-160000507.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"b352b6d6f357fb8c4cb10178d5f7cdb2\">QAnon as a domestic-terrorism group</a>, saying it's filled with \"conspiracy theory-driven domestic extremists\" and citing it as a growing threat.&#160;</p><p>McDaniel suggested that voters are not concerned about QAnon and would rather focus on developments concerning the upcoming coronavirus stimulus package.&#160;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;This Week  (@ThisWeekABC) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1317826477120016389?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 18, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>A poll released last month from Pew Research said <a href=\"https://www.journalism.org/2020/09/16/most-americans-who-have-heard-of-qanon-conspiracy-theories-say-they-are-bad-for-the-country-and-that-trump-seems-to-support-people-who-promote-them/\">47% of respondents</a> had heard of or read about QAnon, more than double the number of people who said the same back in March.&#160; Of the 47% who indicated they were familiar with QAnon, almost three-quarters of respondents said it's \"very bad\" for the country.&#160;</p><p>About 60% of people who said they were familiar with QAnon said they think Trump supports people who promote the movement.&#160;</p><p>QAnon has gained strength in the public eye this year. Dozens of&#160;<a href=\"https://www.mediamatters.org/qanon-conspiracy-theory/here-are-qanon-supporters-running-congress-2020\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.mediamatters.org/qanon-conspiracy-theory/here-are-qanon-supporters-running-congress-2020&source=gmail&ust=1603029620518000&usg=AFQjCNHJv3NnnD8cV1lQbzI6ibBpBaWdKwI6ibBpBaWdKw\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"da9eac344ffe9d4f0e50037993dce750\">local and national political candidates</a>&#160;— as well as&#160;<a href=\"https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2020/09/police-officers-qanon/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2020/09/police-officers-qanon/&source=gmail&ust=1603029620518000&usg=AFQjCNFqcW53R0e6HY7dYJjOq1Vj6_0raQjOq1Vj6_0raQ\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"4b9a274eb692d670f8a4cf4d5e1bf92c\">other people in positions of power</a>&#160;like police officers — have either been linked to the movement or promoted its beliefs.</p><p>There is a growing list of&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-qanon-infiltrated-the-gop-2020-10\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"ca3c0c9a337fa028ba8f30b846926429\">Republican politicians who have either backed or avoided denouncing QAnon</a>. Some, including Sen. Kelly Loeffler of Georgia and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/qanon-supporters-will-rally-for-president-donald-trump-this-weekend-2020-8\">the president</a>, have received and accepted support from the group.&#160;</p><p>Most recently, Trump&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-praises-refuses-to-condemn-qanon-at-nbc-town-hall-2020-10\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"cd0f3845bdc9b234d1d6df52ac6ff46c\">refused to denounce the QAnon movement</a>&#160;while speaking to NBC News' Savannah Guthrie Thursday night during a town hall. He also praised the group multiple times.&#160;</p><p>\"I know nothing about it,\" he said when asked if he would disavow the group and its support. \"I do know they are very much against pedophilia. They fight it very hard. But I know nothing about it.\"</p><p>On Friday, Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, called Trump's refusal to condemn the fringe group \"<a href=\"https://www.axios.com/mitt-romney-trump-qanon-83d36061-15d3-40a5-8d6e-6431165b36f3.html\">alarming</a>.\" Romney is McDaniel's uncle.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/rnc-chair-qanon-is-something-voters-are-not-thinking-about-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=KbEkJM7f5v4:IPgpFYSTk5s:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Pelosi backs Michigan governor who was the target of a foiled kidnapping attempt, slams Trump's rhetoric as 'irresponsible'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/pelosi-backs-whitmer-echoing-claim-that-trumps-rhetoric-is-irresponsible-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f68c88c57b7da001ee12cd9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Nancy Pelosi\" height=\"2000\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Sunday backed up Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer's assertions that President Donald Trump's rhetoric is dangerous and incites violence.&#160;</li>\n<li>Last week, Whitmer was the target of an elaborate kidnapping plot that got foiled by the FBI.&#160;</li>\n<li>Since the men behind the attack have been arrested, Whitmer has accused Trump of using rhetoric that sows division and hatred.&#160;</li>\n<li>\"The president has to realize that words of the president of the United States weigh a ton,\" Pelosi said Sunday, echoing Whitmer's comments.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Sunday echoed Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer's assertions that President Donald Trump's rhetoric is dangerous and incites violence.&#160;</p><p>Whitmer was the target of a foiled kidnapping attempt last week. The FBI said the agency has arrested a group of militia members on charges of suspicion to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fbi-foiled-right-wing-militia-plot-kidnap-michigan-gretchen-whitmer-2020-10\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"39a4e69848fbeed52dfa76c54602ae8f\">plot to kidnap and hold her hostage</a>. The men behind the foiled attempt had been monitoring Whitmer's vacation home and building bombs, according to the FBI.<a href=\"https://eb2.3lift.com/pass?tl_clickthrough=true&redir=https%3A%2F%2Frtb-us-east.linkedin.com%2Flax%2Fclk%3Ftrk%3DCwEAAAF1NpZSH2qijVcMVaLIzksmqAcMvq_WQAQZrpRKlWufE_Ko2OFoDxVX7d91hy7Lg-yklF3XQrL0MPqsiSS-0v_eeLY_Ja71WaGzt6SeEhVRURs8W7VQ-Xngjbyj_wYL6LTQGqh1xA4_pg_zSLWt7lxcSDbD7NQ8VgfbOGk1eqdWvIJaeLLEwnx6sp925XIaTsfHDJu22wdbTcLzCCcBMQOMXV4_7exiuglLap8LW6p9FNVmcoG90pNAzhcsH70-GYwH2oXML3muONpCFXGp_aXZ914-MjExYZ7d8ddftuLP7yprsZCC_OjuVO6RYA3Yt51n6sTiiFGKaB5MwkuKfLrOKiLDVADnqfLQzMkKmTLIsy-Wj6Qbm80Qf8hB-8e2uJ7bjGLDHxe0VK5tHAseJVyAUz9U2qWQhJ1RTcfgWqgwGTlB1QufG-gU8ND_2CbRxFVVWbyMqEkeWE8TLhvo5tXOlgq_JnH6jNxgP2wmXBxQyaS2D7fJIVz5w6BCSfv1NxyukWkhsYRYc8HVP9ryfFFPvxcnVdd_Mbnv7V2hK0KpGRF93AGUgPHT-TlLcssPteezWI4D24eTdYD72hE-4M88HCW0ghc2k-MF5DXrD-3AdZUaFPWcKVSsbKEl-0f8Ix47Hdh0bciYijQdtwnGzqUjhUEWiPSWk68b-JunyAdRXD9BECkHpUJ_nxZzCleNajMjDviVMKWppL6UWgD4uLxiGpn2cE1aSxsk7u2fpcb5U3bOyfN7w361mbqXb7l_KvZij7sSn468uV_P05bntyTT1loSd8-4ESvBIt4puNhqcKZajVSRNiWD9mPoQIGWPLBiaE8_CnSNJpQp6Hf7Ep5hK77LDOaveKmYukLkrRJ2XxGcXct0n1I8UwxcjkwsHPVESQat-X3Prhgr7AOtfUUkxgXEK_5rgqKJrD9Q_ydJKta7WO95fzpJq9Guot6Xby-XZVgsi6TJydDw3vWz820dvCg0pL02-leivUn2i5Yxn0fGMOOswDmITnYuOyYfPOUf69zfqbWeDg4rLNydUVBTagbjnOFPad0-iXqBXQChdZaYIiZHL9MZh6tCh5wPBwSK21PRSnZe9DuYVJkuj2NpyLQIUbwYmMjyTt1VLqUHWnMZLhlzyrL0vq76rXB3jcpSnG8bOYpIXC7lBNJI9MbxbcjUhxEYqTkucKl5MFe1_FQl4m3y5MNtoRIWn6KFKMLvRUcIiC1JJIDBa1WfyjGxJo2iJLFtEhXdEK7kptOVXtzjkClKplQsGnBkCbDnynFGpJCBYr98pYEQUBBvOmAaIkOU1AuGmft_W5NB-v5DfbChxStHdW25oEh9wbu33fAy2ZtQRm83AZRUwb1JzEt7PPUcVM-2K40foe2ylWXe7zJj1rog8CTpOzn9SrwBQ-A69Yh6IetC9J8tAJAkvNTUk4mZ84ob8IyBq7xDytUlU1o8N0tToc-jtOIuqWBE2Pm_vUSh_UtXH5LVm_tEIaYf%26action%3Dclick%26laxrid%3D408ccb6f-730c-4e1e-9750-58070f95e765%26laxbid%3D2%26eid%3D3%26laxerid%3D129830200526795424210%26adfmt%3D6%26urle%3DCwEAAAF1NpZSdF6aaf1mOIigxJXAu_9KjNhPCz0y5SY1sFemjSaWRHSpD1ZKGA0WO2XXzQJIe2AtKwgA23gRMc3NkWuSPfhmHgCMLFtb63emnzqhPmiDX7RBH9TacyDz6PB0YwUwfQgFoOVxFnICSCPQqFreShSz9dp3IHpm-kT51eLEVWUMKqquR3kSDqu8xnt2MfZgQNex%26urlhash%3D1YDx&bc=5.905&pr=3.25&brid=510326&bmid=6250&biid=6250&aid=129830200526795424210&bcud=5905&sid=66552&ts=1602938622&cb=94075amp;sid=66552&#38;ts=1602938622&#38;cb=94075\" kidnapping, Trump had not denounced the men allegedly behind the attack but tore into the governor, saying she's \"done a terrible job.\"&#160;</p><p>\"She locked down her state for everyone, except her husband's boating activities,\" he tweeted.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Donald J. Trump  (@realDonaldTrump) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1314377607379640320?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 9, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Trump at a campaign rally on Saturday <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-crowd-chants-lock-her-up-after-whitmer-kidnapping-plot-2020-10\">again criticized Whitmer</a> for issuing executive orders meant to limit the spread of the coronavirus in Michigan. The crowd responded by chanting \"lock her up,\" a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-special-prosecutor-hillary-clinton-2016-10\">phrase first chanted by Trump supporters</a> during the 2016 presidential election and in reference to Hillary Clinton.&#160;</p><p>\"This is exactly the rhetoric that has put me, my family, and other government officials' lives in danger while we try to save the lives of our fellow Americans,\" Whitmer said in response to Trump's&#160; Saturday rally. \"It needs to stop.\"</p><p>Pelosi backed her up Sunday, characterizing Trump's language as \"irresponsible.\"&#160;</p><p>\"The president has to realize that words of the president of the United States weigh a ton. And in our political dialogue, to inject fear tactics into it — especially a woman governor and her family — is so irresponsible,\" she said on ABC's \"This Week.\"</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;This Week  (@ThisWeekABC) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1317814746016526336?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 18, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>\"And in all fairness to people who listen to him, people think the president is important and what he says should be adhered to,\" she continued. \"And so we have this horrible situation. But the people have awakened to him. 26 million people already voting. The biggest antidote to his poison is the vote.\"</p><p>Other heavyweight lawmakers have also criticized Trump's response following the news of the kidnapping attempt.&#160;</p><p>Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-slams-trump-for-response-to-attempted-kidnapping-michigan-governor-2020-10\">slammed Trump</a> earlier this week, calling his attacks on Whitmer \"despicable.\"</p><p>\"That was a planned act of terrorism, a plot,\" Biden said. \"To kidnap an American leader is the sort of behavior you might expect from ISIS and should shock the conscience of every American, to see that sort of twisted thinking take root here in America.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 2020 14:18:58 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f68c89d57b7da001ee12cdb?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7eb286ec2de25d68aabc03816787af01","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn60@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-16-930_b0708d39809c34f1.webp","destWidth":2666,"destHeight":2000,"sourceBytes":176188,"destBytes":176188,"author":"ydzhanova@businessinsider.com (Yelena Dzhanova)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f68c88c57b7da001ee12cd9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn43@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-29-195_d878c08fcc51741f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=A1OOyDpMUBc:RGYzj4WweoY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn64@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-33-758_17fb0213b8b16909.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=A1OOyDpMUBc:RGYzj4WweoY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn28@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-22-440_ebb46fdf763ee99a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=A1OOyDpMUBc:RGYzj4WweoY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn43@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-23-624_54fb4224518a8516.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/A1OOyDpMUBc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn68@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-33-794_3450845e5330977d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520925},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Why Twitter should let verified health experts report COVID-19 misinformation on the platform, according to 3 physicians","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-twitter-should-let-health-experts-report-covid-19-misinformation-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ecec4c1aee6a824df6df245?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Donald Trump Twitter Phone\" height=\"3123\" width=\"4164\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Twitter doesn&#39;t currently allow users, even verified health experts, to report on false information spread on the app about COVID-19.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/in-this-photo-illustration-a-twitter-logo-is-displayed-on-a-news-photo/1215626364?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">OLIVIER DOULIERY/AFP via Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Twitter recently placed a warning label atop a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1313449844413992961\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">tweet by President Trump</a> in which he falsely claimed it to be less deadly than the seasonal flu, saying the tweet violated Twitter's rules.</li>\n<li>Still, Twitter currently offers no way for users to report information as false or violatory &#8212; finding and labeling misinformation seems to depend on Twitter conducting an internal review.</li>\n<li>Christopher M. Worsham, Lakshman Swamy, and Rahul Ganatra are physicians who say Twitter should let verified health expert users flag false content for the company's review.</li>\n<li>They say this system could utilize the knowledge and people-power of thousands of doctors, and stop false information from rampantly spreading.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Twitter placed a warning label atop a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1313449844413992961\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">tweet by President Trump</a> last week that contained misinformation about COVID-19: He falsely claimed it is less deadly than seasonal influenza. This week it applied the same label to <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1315316071243476997\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">another tweet</a> by the president containing misinformation about COVID-19 immunity.</p><p>The label warns that the tweets violate Twitter's rules, and the company's executives&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/10/06/us/trump-covid-live-updates/facebook-removes-trump-post-that-compared-the-pandemic-to-the-flu-saying-it-spread-coronavirus-misinformation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">assured the New York Times</a>&#160;that by placing the label on a tweet, \"engagements with the tweet will be significantly limited.\"</p><p>Since there is currently no way for users to report tweets like this to Twitter as COVID-19 misinformation, we presume the label was added after the company's internal review which, like Facebook and other social media platforms, is facing increased scrutiny for its role in spreading misinformation about the coronavirus. While the president himself is a <a href=\"https://www.vox.com/coronavirus-covid19/21497221/donald-trump-covid-19-coronavirus-news-misinformation-study\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">significant, high-profile source</a> of online COVID-19 misinformation, he is not the only one creating and spreading it. And though alerting users to misinformation is an important step, Twitter offers few tools for knowledgeable users to combat abundant and sometimes <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2020/04/trump-bleach-coronavirus/610690/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">deadly misinformation</a>&#160;spreading on the platform.</p><p>This spring, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/TwitterSupport/status/1241155701822476288\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Twitter released information</a> about a special verification process for physicians and public health leaders that aimed to empower credible and credentialed individuals with various types of health expertise to disseminate and evaluate emerging information on COVID-19.</p><p>Twitter began <a href=\"https://help.twitter.com/en/managing-your-account/about-twitter-verified-accounts\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">verifying certain user accounts</a>&#160;in 2009 as a means of combating impersonation, saying \"An account may be verified if it is determined to be an account of public interest. Typically this includes accounts maintained by users in music, acting, fashion, government, politics, religion, journalism, media, sports, business, and&#160;<a href=\"https://help.twitter.com/en/managing-your-account/about-twitter-verified-accounts\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">other key interest areas.\"</a>&#160;A verified Twitter account is marked with a small blue checkmark next to the user's name.</p><p>We hoped this special verification process was the beginning of an effort to combat misinformation about COVID-19 by crowdsourcing expertise to verified health experts. The three of us, along with many other physicians and experts, were verified under this program.</p><p>But despite using verification to elevate credible voices to share essential information about COVID-19, these efforts have not meaningfully reduced the spread of misinformation. In fact, verified experts who came across misinformation and tried to identify it as such by replying to or quoting the tweet may have unwittingly amplified it. This strategy has essentially amounted to watering the garden without pulling the weeds. The result has been that users still cannot easily tell the difference between a tweet that is simply widely shared from one that is credible.</p><p>Both&#160;<a href=\"https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2020/updating-our-approach-to-misleading-information.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Twitter</a>&#160;and&#160;<a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/communitystandards/false_news\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Facebook</a>&#160;have rules against sharing misinformation as well as internal systems to flag or remove tweets that violate their rules. Facebook, relying on artificial intelligence and human fact-checker review,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/08/11/facebook-covid-misinformation-takedowns/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reported this week</a> that it has removed seven million posts containing COVID-19 misinformation and applied warning labels on another 98 million. These systems, however, can be <a href=\"https://www.npr.org/2020/10/09/921791419/tiny-changes-let-false-claims-about-covid-19-voting-evade-facebook-fact-checks\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">easily evaded</a>&#160;and have not come close to solving the problem on any platform.</p><p>On Twitter, which has already made the effort to verify the expertise of some of its users, there is an obvious opportunity to try something new: Let verified experts report COVID-19 misinformation. This would result in more flagged-content reports for Twitter to sort through.</p><p>A key difference between these and reports of other types of abuse — spam, harassment, hate speech, threats of violence, misleading information about an election, and the like — is that these reports would be generated by users already verified as health experts. With the ability to report tweets to Twitter as COVID-19 misinformation, experts can identify them without amplifying the message.</p><p>Tweets that have been reported to contain clear misinformation, such as those denouncing the benefits of social distancing, mask use, or the existence of the virus at all, should be quickly marked as such when discovered. Because existing internal systems have proven to be incompletely effective, Twitter could tap into the verified expertise of some of its users to let other users know they are looking at a tweet that contains misinformation — a weed instead of a flower.</p><p>Clearly, the label of \"misinformation\" must be applied with caution, and only in situations where there is clear scientific consensus. We are not advocating for censorship, just the ability for expert users to identify instances of the 2020 equivalent of falsely yelling \"Fire!\" in a crowded theater.</p><p>Twitter has been a useful platform for discussion in areas of active scientific debate, and it would be a terrible mistake to use misinformation labels to stifle conversation in areas where there is no clear-cut scientific consensus. The platform has previously found ways to exercise judgment in marking other types of rule violations, such as labeling tweets containing misleadingly edited videos as \"Manipulated media\" and placing fact-checking flags to link users to accurate information about voting. We trust that judgment could be similarly exercised with COVID-19 misinformation in accordance with existing rules and clearly delineated criteria for what constitutes misinformation.</p><p>While we appreciate Twitter's attempt to elevate important public health information during the pandemic, we see a missed opportunity to curb misinformation. As physicians and avid Twitter users, we value the ability to communicate directly with patients and colleagues in a public forum. Educating and learning from the public is an important aspect of our work as physicians and subject-matter experts, and while verification enhances our ability to fulfill that mission, we need tools beyond a blue checkmark to do our part to slow the spread of misinformation.</p><p><em>Christopher M. Worsham is a pulmonologist and critical care physician at Massachusetts General Hospital and a research fellow at Harvard Medical School. Lakshman Swamy is a pulmonologist and critical care physician at Cambridge Health Alliance. Rahul Ganatra is an internal medicine physician at VA Boston Healthcare System and an instructor in medicine at Harvard Medical School. The views expressed here are the authors' and do not necessarily represent the views of their employers.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/why-twitter-should-let-health-experts-report-covid-19-misinformation-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=4VPSBHFxzmY:Pk-LnmW6KO0:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=4VPSBHFxzmY:Pk-LnmW6KO0:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=4VPSBHFxzmY:Pk-LnmW6KO0:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=4VPSBHFxzmY:Pk-LnmW6KO0:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=4VPSBHFxzmY:Pk-LnmW6KO0:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=4VPSBHFxzmY:Pk-LnmW6KO0:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=4VPSBHFxzmY:Pk-LnmW6KO0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=4VPSBHFxzmY:Pk-LnmW6KO0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/4VPSBHFxzmY\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 18 Oct 2020 13:30:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5ecec4c1aee6a824df6df245?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"2cdec757b51cfa640388dd06c9832e17","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn16@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-01-348_1b8a5d2a859e366f.webp","destWidth":4164,"destHeight":3123,"sourceBytes":178656,"destBytes":178656,"author":"insider@insider.com (Christopher M. 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Toyota is creating a Lunar Cruiser for Japan's space exploration agency — take a look","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/toyota-and-japan-aerospace-exploration-agency-lunar-cruiser-collaboration-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7de3a5282c500018c791c0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"20190312_01_03\" height=\"1405\" width=\"1874\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lunar Cruiser.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Toyota</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) and Toyota are working together to design a pressurized space rover.</li>\n<li>The vehicle will be called the Lunar Cruiser, a reference to Toyota's Land Cruiser.&#160;</li>\n<li>They signed an agreement in 2019, with plans to launch in the late 2020s.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The future of space exploration might be in the form of public-private partnerships, like the one between the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) and Toyota to create a <a href=\"https://global.toyota/en/newsroom/corporate/27059582.html\">manned, electric rover.</a></p><p>Jaxa and Toyota first agreed to partner in March 2019, when they said that they would start technological studies. Manned rovers like the one the are collaborating on will play an \"important role in full-fledged exploration and use of the lunar surface\" JAXA President Hiroshi Yamakawa said.&#160;</p><p>Toyota and Jaxa revealed concept designs for the rover, which they announced in August will be called the <a href=\"https://global.toyota/en/newsroom/corporate/33208872.html\">Lunar Cruiser</a> as a reference to Toyota's famous Land Cruiser. Throughout the rest of 2020, they are working on manufacturing test pieces of the design, with plans to launch by the end of the decade.</p><p>Take a look at the Lunar Cruiser plans here.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tThe Lunar Cruiser concept is about 20 feet by 17 feet, and 12 feet tall. In comparison, it is about the size of two minibuses.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7de0fc94fce90018f7ba34?format=jpeg\" alt=\"20190312_01_04_2\" height=\"1405\" width=\"1874\" people.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f776ad60ab50d00184ade6f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"20190312_01_01_2\" height=\"1405\" width=\"1874\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lunar Cruiser.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Toyota</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe design has some difficult parameters to meet: it must be able to travel on the moon's surface for six weeks, and astronauts must be able to remove their suits safely inside.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7de06994fce90018f7ba2d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"20190312_01_03\" height=\"1405\" width=\"1874\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lunar Cruiser.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Toyota</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIts first mission is planned to encompass 6,200 miles in 42 days.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7de0d4282c500018c791aa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"20190312_01_06_2\" height=\"1263\" width=\"1684\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lunar Cruiser.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Toyota</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tTo harness the energy for this journey, Toyota is planning to use a next generation fuel cell, capable of traveling about 620 miles on one tank.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7de0b3282c500018c791a8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"20190312_01_02\" height=\"1405\" width=\"1874\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lunar Cruiser.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Toyota</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tDays and nights on the moon each last for two weeks, so the cruiser will also generate electricity using solar panels.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7de114282c500018c791b0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"20190312_01_05\" height=\"1405\" width=\"1874\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lunar Cruiser.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Toyota</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBecause of the long night period, that energy will need to be stored for later use. The fuel cell can also use water from the electricity generation process for cooling and drinking water.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7de0ea282c500018c791ac?format=jpeg\" have automated driving functions.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7de13494fce90018f7ba35?format=jpeg\" alt=\"20190312_01_07_2\" height=\"1405\" width=\"1874\" Meisenzahl)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f7de3a5282c500018c791c0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn40@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-16-873_ced8234f7e2a1f96.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7de0fc94fce90018f7ba34?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn12@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-30-850_8a6573186de37955.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f776ad60ab50d00184ade6f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn99@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-18-319_e7a3931f0471f387.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7de06994fce90018f7ba2d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn18@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-25-190_ff1fc548effaf9c0.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7de0d4282c500018c791aa?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn27@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-28-193_6f0da865b6a91789.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7de0b3282c500018c791a8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn96@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-30-590_27c1cd088d02c482.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7de114282c500018c791b0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn80@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-20-878_f27d4f86adee7152.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7de0ea282c500018c791ac?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn52@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-844_684de7f009c5a81c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7de13494fce90018f7ba35?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn76@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-33-804_e8c24b6942518232.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Yp5ska8wiec:eaLzK-CHjJU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn67@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-35-609_257f03febf14a0cf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Yp5ska8wiec:eaLzK-CHjJU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn51@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-20-682_dc5868815e4e9182.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Yp5ska8wiec:eaLzK-CHjJU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn83@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-31-534_5d47862d7fb2773c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Yp5ska8wiec":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn83@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-20-901_c162daa582e31053.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520919},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Use this equation to calculate the true value of your time and how much you should be paid","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-set-rates-calculate-true-value-of-time-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ea1a1635bd7a55bee200ef8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"freelancer stimulus bill coronavirus\" height=\"4000\" width=\"6000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Before calculating your time, consider how many un-billable hours you might have to work.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Westend61/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Learning how to calculate your time as money can be a valuable tool, especially if you need to determine your rates as a freelancer or consultant.</li>\n<li>Focus on finding an in-demand solution or service to clients that has potential to scale and increase in value over time.&#160;</li>\n<li>Then, you can divide your earnings by how much billable time you've put in to accurately calculate your hourly rate.&#160;</li>\n<li>This equation works both for freelancers as well as business leader and employers trying to determine if an independent contractor's rate is fair.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>In&#160;<a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/business\" data-ga-category=\"autotag-linking\" data-ga-label=\"ai-metadata\" data-ga-action=\"/topic/business\">business</a>, if you've heard it once, then you've heard it a thousand times —&#160;<a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/time\" data-ga-category=\"autotag-linking\" data-ga-label=\"ai-metadata\" data-ga-action=\"/topic/time\">time</a>&#160;is&#160;<a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/money\" data-ga-category=\"autotag-linking\" data-ga-label=\"ai-metadata\" data-ga-action=\"/topic/money\">money</a>. But just&#160;<em>how much</em>&#160;money? If you're freelancing or consulting, how do you figure out just what you're worth to other people?</p><h2>The alternative to the comparative, hourly default</h2><p>To start, you might be tempted to just use a per-hour rate. You might look at what others make for similar work to set that rate for yourself.</p><p>However, this isn't a great solution. You'll quickly hit a ceiling in terms of production, because&#160;there are only so many hours in a day to do the real work&#160;<em>and</em>&#160;all the un-billable, behind-the-scenes tasks involved like&#160;<a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/marketing\" data-ga-category=\"autotag-linking\" data-ga-label=\"ai-metadata\" data-ga-action=\"/topic/marketing\">marketing</a>. And let's not forget that some clients like paying only a flat fee based on whether you finish a specific task, and that some projects will vary widely in terms of what's required of you.&#160;</p><p>To accommodate different situations and make sure you don't limit yourself to only selling your hours, you want to focus instead on finding something that's both scalable and in fantastic demand by a huge number of people. For example, I once did an analysis that looked at billionaires and how they're distributed —&#160;this showed that the biggest&#160;<a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/wealth\" data-ga-category=\"autotag-linking\" data-ga-label=\"ai-metadata\" data-ga-action=\"/topic/wealth\">wealth</a> or demand areas are housing, clothing, food, energy, and computers.&#160;</p><p>Now, the products or services within those areas might look very different in the future. But those basic categories aren't going anywhere. So, find a niche within these groups where you can scale and scale and scale —&#160;the cloud is a great example. As you keep scaling up over time and your sales increase, your monetary value will get higher, too. And, to find that value at any given point along the way, all you have to do is divide your earnings by how much billable time you've put in.&#160;</p><p>Let's look at an example. Let's say you're the CEO of Company Awesome. You're pulling in $100,000 a year. And let's assume that you're lucky to get 1,000 billable hours per year out of the 2,000 you could work. Doing the math ($100,000/1,000 hours) means you're worth $100 per hour. Similarly, if you're running a $200 million company and get in 1,200 billable hours, then your value is $200 million/1,200, which is a cool $166,666 per hour.</p><h2>Every minute counts</h2><p>Now, let's step back for a second. Yes, this simple formula lets you figure out what you could stand to earn. That's great for financial planning and living the way you want. But the bigger lesson is that every minute counts. When you understand what the true monetary value of your time is, you're not going to waste the hours of your day. It's easier to see that fooling around or being inefficient really does cost you, and that it's monetarily beneficial to be as professional as possible.</p><h2>The value of your team and experts</h2><p>You can apply these ideas to your workforce, too. For instance, if you can attribute $500,000 in gains to somebody on your team and they worked 1,000 hours for you, then they've got an hourly value of $500. Don't shortchange them. Every worker, regardless of level, deserves to understand what they're worth to the business, and you should reevaluate pay regularly to ensure that you're treating everybody fairly based on how the company's doing. If that value doesn't go directly into a paycheck, then they need to be able to see how you are reinvesting on their behalf to provide real security, safety, and personal opportunity. Otherwise, they might assume that you're simply lining your own pockets.</p><p>In the same way, when you bring in an expert and their rate looks absurd, take a pause. Think about how their work has translated into profits, market share, or other assets at other businesses. If that yield is high, they might be well justified in asking for a particular rate. Or conversely, if you do your homework and find out that the yield is just ho-hum, you might be justified in negotiating a lower rate or just moving on to somebody else.</p><p>The only truly limited resource that everyone has in common is&#160;<em>time</em>. Every moment you have matters. When you understand the worth of those moments based on earned yearly income and billable hours, you can keep yourself more accountable and advocate for yourself financially with confidence. And when you know the value of others' time, it's easier to treat them with fairness and respect, too. So, do the math. The equation is simple, and the unquantifiable benefits are free.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"This $103,190 tiny home on wheels was a true product of the pandemic after the company pivoted during lockdown — see inside the 'Dark Horse'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/dark-horse-tiny-home-on-wheels-designed-pandemic-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6a044757b7da001ee13058?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dark Horse tiny home\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Dark Horse tiny home.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.buildtiny.co.nz/dark-horse\" target=\"_blank\">Build Tiny</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Build Tiny unveiled its latest tiny home on wheels: <a href=\"https://www.buildtiny.co.nz/dark-horse\">the $103,190 Dark Horse</a>, which was designed and constructed during the pandemic.</li>\n<li>The single-level Dark Horse has a bedroom, living room, kitchen with a breakfast bar, and a dual-purpose laundry and bathroom.</li>\n<li>The conception of the Dark Horse came when two of Build Tiny's customers backed out of projects amid the pandemic, leaving the team of builders with a gap in their schedule.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Build Tiny has unveiled its latest project: <a href=\"https://www.buildtiny.co.nz/dark-horse\">the Dark Horse</a>, an approximately $103,190 tiny home on wheels that was designed and constructed during the pandemic.</p><p>Build Tiny specializes in, you guessed it, building custom tiny homes that sit on trailer chassis. This one in particular has a bedroom, living space, kitchen with a breakfast bar, and a dual purpose laundry and bathroom.</p><p>But unlike most of the New Zealand-based company's little homes on wheels, the Dark Horse wasn't created for or named by a client. Instead, it was designed and built in-house by the team of builders that then had to come up with and vote on its name, the latter a task that's normally delegated to the client.</p><p>\"The thinking behind it is ... a 'dark horse' is a term usually used to refer to someone that was previously taken for granted, but rose to prominence in a situation — something akin to an underdog success story,\" <a href=\"https://www.buildtiny.co.nz/our-people\">Build Tiny's director and designer Gina Stevens</a> told Business Insider in an email interview. \"That's how we view ourselves as a company in some ways, and also the tiny house is quite unassuming from the outside, but has a few surprises on the inside.\"</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tThe naming and building anomaly was a result of New Zealand's coronavirus-induced lockdown in mid-March that caused Build Tiny to temporarily shutter production efforts.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6a04ae57b7da001ee1305f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dark Horse tiny home\" height=\"1669\" width=\"2225\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Dark Horse tiny home.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.buildtiny.co.nz/dark-horse\" target=\"_blank\">Build Tiny</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tDuring this time, two of its clients pulled out of their plans to order a tiny home, leaving only three units in the workshop instead of the typical five.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6a050257b7da001ee13066?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dark Horse tiny home\" height=\"1869\" width=\"2492\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Dark Horse tiny home.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.buildtiny.co.nz/dark-horse\" target=\"_blank\">Build Tiny</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAs a result, by the time the company could resume operations eight weeks later, the builders had two \"gaps\" in their work schedule.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6a04b957b7da001ee13060?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dark Horse tiny home\" height=\"1669\" width=\"2225\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Dark Horse tiny home.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.buildtiny.co.nz/dark-horse\" target=\"_blank\">Build Tiny</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIn order to fill this gap, Stevens designed the Dark Horse, allowing the company to introduce a new tiny home while giving the builders something to work on.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6a04c457b7da001ee13062?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dark Horse tiny home\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Dark Horse tiny home.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.buildtiny.co.nz/dark-horse\" target=\"_blank\">Build Tiny</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThis process differs from Build Tiny's normal workflow, which is often based on custom orders as requested by clients.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img single level homes.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6a05ac323fc4001e0d7aff?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dark Horse tiny home\" height=\"1874\" width=\"2499\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Dark Horse tiny home.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.buildtiny.co.nz/dark-horse\" target=\"_blank\">Build Tiny</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tDespite slight tiny home order fulfillment and delivery delays when the lockdown was first lifted, the company is now back on schedule.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6a04d1323fc4001e0d7af3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dark Horse tiny home\" height=\"1669\" width=\"2225\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Dark Horse tiny home.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.buildtiny.co.nz/dark-horse\" target=\"_blank\">Build Tiny</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAnd with the help of New Zealand's COVID-19 Wage Subsidy, Build Tiny was able to pay its employees 80% of their wage even through lockdown.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6a06f7323fc4001e0d7b17?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dark Horse tiny home\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Dark Horse [another build for one of the company's directors], we would have had to reduce the working hours for our build team,\" Stevens wrote. \"However, had this occurred, we would have had the government wage subsidy to fall back on again ...\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6a04dd57b7da001ee13064?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dark Horse tiny home\" height=\"1669\" width=\"2225\"
