Meisenzahl)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f89c377d260780019341d96?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn83@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-28-467_d444e47cbef651bb.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89b8679e9fe40019009c1d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn96@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-18-422_4fba8029dda6d8cc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89b5af9e9fe40019009c08?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn28@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-29-014_752283f9d0e50e4c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c212d260780019341d8a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn55@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-20-662_704915d5f58590c6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89ac639e9fe40019009bba?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn56@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-21-671_6e3e50e1b038074b.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c3c69e9fe40019009c73?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn12@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-35-695_de691feb6135b086.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f0c7ed63f737013dc7bb75a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn76@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-33-179_c350bc9c607d1796.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c4549e9fe40019009c76?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn31@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-29-917_55e0a4df13b50384.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89ac4b9e9fe40019009bb9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn76@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-18-950_6de1fada7245a8e2.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c49c9e9fe40019009c78?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn31@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-35-348_493317976def6844.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c58f9e9fe40019009c7e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn39@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-18-917_b6a638e5709e4410.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c62cd260780019341da9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn84@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-24-834_de3cd38b560f76a7.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c68dd260780019341daf?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn27@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-23-498_1d56f3609ec26f67.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c6219e9fe40019009c81?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn20@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-20-121_e3e131016a952a25.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c5e69e9fe40019009c80?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn88@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-27-695_74d4f69723cdd998.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c732d260780019341db1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn8@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-28-754_ed585bc4742ba491.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c77d9e9fe40019009c8a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn8@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-24-338_9b8a09afa0074c3a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89c8b89e9fe40019009c94?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn5@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-01-276_7a3d75f7d6acc101.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=XfazShY9QDI:JJ2Syct_acc:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-33-614_262c9af9ed0fedd4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=XfazShY9QDI:JJ2Syct_acc:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn79@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-16-945_ecaa118693cd10a8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=XfazShY9QDI:JJ2Syct_acc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn11@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-34-254_864cada32b1e7f03.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/XfazShY9QDI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn91@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-19-813_d951d4f351081b92.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520924},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"There's a simple and effective way the government can help Americans through devastating emergencies like the pandemic: just give people cash","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/tennessee-wildfire-victims-direct-cash-successful-covid-pandemic-economy-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7501780ab50d00184ad778?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Unemployment benefits line\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Hundreds of unemployed Kentucky residents wait in long lines outside the Kentucky Career Center for help with their unemployment claims on June 19, 2020 in Frankfort, Kentucky.\n<p class=\"copyright\">John Sommers II/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>People do not have the financial resilience to navigate emergencies in today's economy.</li>\n<li>Unconditional cash assistance helps people stabilize and prepare for future emergencies.</li>\n<li>After 2016 wildfires in Tennessee, Dolly Parton and the My People Fund pledged to provide $1,000 per month for six months to each family who lost their homes.</li>\n<li>The results showed that the direct cash payments did not disincentivize work and helped people get through the crisis.</li>\n<li>The study and others shows that now is the time to consider guaranteed income as part of a 21st century social safety net.&#160;</li>\n<li>Stacy Elliott is a Ph.D. student and graduate research assistant for the College of Social Work at the University of Tennessee.</li>\n<li>\n<p>Stacia Martin-West is an Assistant Professor in the College of Social Work at the University of Tennessee.</p>\n</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>As the entire West Coast deals with the fallout from massive wildfires and our nation continues to struggle through a once-in-a-generation pandemic, we can learn a great deal about how to help people in emergencies from unconditional cash disbursements we studied in Gatlinburg, Tennessee.</p><p>As we continue to navigate a once-in-a-generation pandemic the findings of our work in Gatlinburg demonstrate just how powerful cash can be in an emergency. Not only does cash assistance not cause folks to drop their employment, but it helps them navigate and prepare for future emergencies better than other other forms of aid. With hyper partisan gridlock preventing Americans from receiving badly needed stimulus checks, this moment gives us pause to consider cash as a permanent part of the social safety net.&#160;</p><p>In November 2016, devastating wildfires destroyed approximately 1,300 residences leaving local families in emotional and economic crisis. Dolly Parton and the My People Fund pledged to provide $1,000 per month for six months to each family who lost their homes. Here's what happened.</p><h2><strong>People don't stop working when we give them money</strong></h2><p>Despite receiving $1,000 per month for five months and a $5,000 cash transfer at the end of the program, recipients maintained employment and their regular work hours.&#160;</p><p>One of the most prevalent myths of cash transfers or guaranteed income is that receiving cash assistance disincentivizes folks from working or maintaining their level of employment.&#160; Our results indicate that this myth is false — recipients maintained about the same amount of employment and work hours before and during disbursement of the monthly $1,000.&#160;</p><h2><strong>People are better able to prepare themselves for future trouble when they have an income floor&#160;</strong></h2><p>Reported savings rates and amounts of savings to weather a future financial emergency increased substantially from the first to second observation. As with many forested areas on the West Coast, the next wildfire emergency in East Tennessee is a matter of <em>when, </em>not if, so having emergency savings in preparation for future wildfires is invaluable.&#160;</p><p>While the wildfires in 2016 were especially deadly and destructive, a major wildfire emergency happens in the Gatlinburg/Sevier County area of Tennessee about every decade or two, and climate change patterns hold important implications for longer, dryer summers and greater risks of future wildfires.</p><h2><strong>Folks are better able to manage emotional challenges when finances are more stable</strong></h2><p>Following the fires, there was a sharp increase in reported symptoms of depression and anxiety in the sample. However, there was a parallel rise in reported treatment-seeking behaviors for those symptoms.&#160;</p><p>Results indicated that wildfire survivors had higher rates of reporting symptoms of depression and anxiety, and the rate of reporting symptoms was sustained across time, even during and after receiving cash transfers. The good news though, was the parallel rise of reported treatment-seeking, such as going to therapy or the doctor to treat depression and anxiety.</p><h2><strong>Cash works best</strong></h2><p>In the final survey, recipients were asked which form of assistance was most helpful (other forms included donations from charity and churches, services from Red Cross and disaster relief, donated goods from friends and family, etc.) and the majority of respondents reported that the monthly cash transfers were the most helpful form of support above all others. With this, the study concluded that cash transfers may be an important, underutilized approach to recovery following an emergency.&#160;</p><p>As a lead researcher on the<a href=\"https://www.stocktondemonstration.org/\"> Stockton Economic Empowerment Demonstration</a> (SEED), the first mayor-led guaranteed income pilot in the country, we weren't intending to look at the impact of GI as traditional disaster relief, but rather its impact on the ongoing emergency of income volatility that folks are living with daily.&#160;</p><p>Though our focuses are different, we are seeing<a href=\"https://seed.sworps.tennessee.edu/\"> similar data</a>. Only 2% of people in the study report they are unemployed and not looking for work. When they began receiving the funds, they<a href=\"https://seed.sworps.tennessee.edu/spending.html\"> spent it</a> how anyone would — on food, merchandise and utilities. And recipients report having been able to prepare for future financial emergencies and navigate the unexpected emergencies<a href=\"https://www.stocktondemonstration.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/COVID-Crisis-Spending-Data-Press-Release.pdf\"> brought on by the pandemic</a>.&#160;</p><p>We are also studying how changes in income volatility alter financial well-being, psychological distress, and physical functioning. We plan to release these data at the culmination of the research in 2021. Though the research is still in progress, anecdotal information provided through the<a href=\"https://seed.sworps.tennessee.edu/spending.html#narrative\"> storytelling efforts</a> demonstrate a positive impact.</p><p>There is legislation introduced for a limited guaranteed income to lift the economy and help Americans weather the pandemic, but now with the second state of emergency 2020 has seen it is clear that folks do not have the financial resilience to navigate emergencies in today's economy, personal or pandemic sized.&#160;</p><p>As we consider solutions to help Americans remain solvent in an era of constant emergencies, we must look at the evidence that supports ongoing guaranteed income as part of the 21st century social safety net.</p><p><em>Stacy Elliott is a Ph.D. student and graduate research assistant for the College of Social Work at the University of Tennessee. Stacia Martin-West is an Assistant Professor in the College of Social Work at the University of Tennessee.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Manor&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Eike Schroter/Netflix</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Netflix has a pair of original hits this week with \"Emily in Paris\" and \"The very different Netflix originals, \"The Haunting of Bly Manor\" and \"Emily in Paris,\" dominated the streaming giant this week.&#160;</p><p>Netflix introduced daily top 10 lists of its most viewed movies and TV shows in February (it counts a view if an account watches at least two minutes of a title).</p><p>Every week,&#160;<a href=\"https://reelgood.com/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"f31f5072d3c303e73f0408b12527e204\">the streaming search engine Reelgood</a>&#160;compiles for Business Insider a list of which TV shows have been most NPR (season one)</p>\n\t5. \"Evil\" (CBS, 2019-present)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d72a6e96f24eb2d320dfc23?format=jpeg\" alt=\"evil\" height=\"485\" width=\"728\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A trio investigates a church&#39;s backlog of perplexing, unsolved accounts.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"http://www.zimbio.com/New&#43;Fall&#43;TV&#43;Shows&#43;To&#43;Watch&#43;If&#43;You&#43;Love&#43;%27The&#43;Haunting&#43;Of&#43;Hill&#43;House%27\" target=\"_blank\">CBS</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.netflix.com/title/81190640\">Description</a>:</strong> \"A forensic psychologist partners with a Catholic priest-in-training to investigate miracles and demonic possession in this supernatural drama.\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: 91%</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: \"This delightful first season has pitted poor, unprepared humans against all manner of techno-torment: hackers, misogynist social networks, deepfakes, videogames your kids don't tell you about, freaking YouTube videos.\" &#8212; <a href=\"https://ew.com/tv-reviews/2020/01/30/cbs-evil-season-1-finale-review/\">Entertainment Weekly</a> (season one)</p>\n\t4. \"The 100\" (The CW, 2014-2020)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5eb4698ffc593d12c0072b94?format=jpeg\" alt=\"the 100 eliza taylor the cw\" height=\"708\" width=\"1260\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Eliza Taylor stars on &#34;The 100.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shane Harvey/The CW</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.netflix.com/title/70283264?source=35\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"A century after Earth was devastated by a nuclear apocalypse, 100 space station residents are sent to the planet to determine whether it's habitable.\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: 93%</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: \"There's a new set of mysteries and stakes this season that will keep fans on the edge of their seats, and which will end, fittingly, on a full one hundred episodes.\" &#8212; <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/lindamaleh/2020/05/20/review-the-100-season-7-raises-the-stakes-in-its-final-season/#ec50f3d77e2b\">Forbes</a> (season seven)</p>\n\t3. \"Schitt's Creek\" (Pop TV, 2015-2020)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5bc49a609fb84c171971e786?format=jpeg\" alt=\"schitts creek\" height=\"675\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Netflix</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.netflix.com/title/80036165\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"8afbc5fa6880a794f7f1d4ce77398357\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"Suddenly broke, the formerly filthy-rich Rose family is reduced to living in a ramshackle motel in a town they once bought as a joke: 'Schitt's Creek.'\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: 93%</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: \"It is safe to say that viewers satisfyingly lived, laughed and loved with their favourite TV family one last time.\" &#8212; <a href=\"https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/television/article-schitts-creek-finale-provides-a-boatload-of-happy-endings/\">Globe and Mail</a> (season six)</p>\n\t2. \"Emily in Paris\" (Netflix original, 2020-present)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f79fee4282c500018c787b4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Emily in Paris netflix\" height=\"1191\" width=\"1588\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Netflix</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.netflix.com/title/81037371\">Description</a>:</strong> \"After landing her dream job in Paris, Chicago marketing exec Emily Cooper embraces her adventurous new life while juggling work, friends and romance.\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: 69%</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: \"Understand, these are tough times and vacuous, fluff-headed, indulgent, fanciful entertainment has its place. But 'Emily in Paris' is pretty far from entertaining.\" &#8212; <a href=\"https://www.detroitnews.com/story/entertainment/television/2020/10/01/review-empty-headed-emily-paris-fails-charm/3585834001/\">Detroit News</a> (season one)</p>\n\t1. \"The Haunting of Bly Manor\" (Netflix original, 2020)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4d01227ffa48002894d1a7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"haunting of bly manor\" height=\"1414\" width=\"1891\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Netflix</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><a href=\"https://www.netflix.com/title/81237854?source=35\"><strong>Description</strong></a>: \"Dead doesn't mean gone. An au pair plunges into an abyss of chilling secrets in this gothic romance from the creator of 'The Haunting of Hill House.'\"</p><p><strong>Rotten Tomatoes critic score</strong>: 86%</p><p><strong>What critics said</strong>: \"'Bly Manor' stands as an ambitious blend of genres and arrives at its ultimate point with proper gravity. It's not a great ghost story, it's not a great love story, but it's still haunting enough to hear out.\" &#8212; <a Welcome to this weekly roundup of Business Insider stories from co-Editor in Chief Matt Turner.&#160;</em><strong><a href=\"http://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/insider-weekly\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"d9a82e56703288f84894c3fc96ee240e\"><em>Subscribe here to get this newsletter in your inbox every Sunday.</em></a></strong></p><p><em>Read on for <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-campaign-nearly-went-broke-amid-200-million-budget-shortfall-2020-10\">the inside story on the Trump campaign's finances</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/writer-anand-giridharadas-slams-corporate-directors-2020-10\">Anand Giridharadas lambasting corporate board members</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-technology-impacting-management-consulting-firms-disruption-future-jobs-2020-10\">a new threat to the management consulting industry</a>.</em></p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89bd879e9fe40019009c46?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trump silhouette\" height=\"2664\" width=\"4000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>US President Donald Trump looks on as he departs a rally at Toledo Express Airport in Swanton, Ohio on September 21, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/president-donald-trump-looks-on-as-he-departs-a-rally-at-news-photo/1228645585?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">MANDEL NGAN/AFP via Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Hello</p><p>The US election, now just a few weeks away, continues to dominate the news cycle. Here's what's trending on <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/\">Insider</a> right now:</p><section><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/spies-hunter-biden-emails-trump-giuliani-vulnerable-russian-intelligence-2020-10\">US spies say the Hunter Biden email controversy shows how 'exploitable' and 'grotesquely vulnerable' Trump and Giuliani are to Russian intelligence</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/eric-trump-shares-misleading-claim-about-old-joe-biden-property-2020-10\">Eric Trump tried to make Biden look corrupt by sharing a picture of a palatial house he claims the Democrat lives in — but Biden sold it 24 years ago</a><br><section></section></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/business-nonprofit-groups-call-trump-withdraw-executive-order-diversity-training-2020-10\">Over 160 business groups call on President Trump to withdraw executive order banning some diversity trainings</a></li></ul><p>There was big news in New York politics this week as Citigroup's vice chairman Raymond McGuire resigned to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/profile-citigroup-banker-nyc-mayoral-candidate-raymond-mcguire-2020-10\">announce his candidacy for New York City mayor</a>. Dakin Campbell spoke to those close to McGuire, along with political strategists, to get the inside story on McGuire's decision to run, and the biggest challenges he'll face.&#160;You can read that story in full here:</p><section><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/profile-citigroup-banker-nyc-mayoral-candidate-raymond-mcguire-2020-10\">Inside Ray McGuire's decision to jump from Citigroup to running for New York City mayor, and the biggest challenges he'll face in trying to win the job</a></strong></li></ul></section></section><hr><h1>Trump's campaign nearly went broke for the 2020 homestretch</h1><p>From Tom LoBianco:</p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Before his demotion this summer as President Donald Trump's campaign manager, Brad Parscale had planned for a stunning amount of money to arrive during the 2020 homestretch that would have covered equally shocking spending but left the reelection effort dead broke by the start of October, three Republicans close to the president's campaign told Insider.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Parscale had been banking on campaign donations to miraculously double in October by about $200 million more than other recent months, one Republican close to the president said. The Republican said Trump's new campaign team, led by Bill Stepien, had to rush to cancel the spending approved by Parscale to salvage the president's bid for a second term.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>But money has been tight since then, leaving no less than the president himself to attempt to beat back stories that his campaign is on the rocks and float the idea, again, that he would open up his own checkbook to keep it running.&#160;</em></p><p>Read the full story here:</p><section><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-campaign-nearly-went-broke-amid-200-million-budget-shortfall-2020-10\">Trump's campaign nearly went broke for the 2020 homestretch amid Brad Parscale's $200 million budgeting misfire, Republicans tell Insider</a></strong></li></ul><p>Also read:</p><section><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-world-braces-for-blowout-loss-playing-the-blame-game-2020-10\">Let the blame game begin. Republicans point the finger at Parscale, Kushner, Stepien, and Trump himself as the president's team braces for a potential 2020 blowout.</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-qanon-infiltrated-the-gop-2020-10\">How the GOP learned to love QAnon</a><br><section></section></li></ul><hr><h2>Anand Giridharadas lambasts corporate board members</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ced637df2f4795c940a3ebe?format=jpeg\" alt=\"anand giridharadas\" height=\"2000\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Virginia Heffernan (L) and Anand Giridharadas speak onstage at WIRED25 Festival: WIRED Celebrates 25th Anniversary  Day 2 on October 14, 2018 in San Francisco, California.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matt Winkelmeyer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>From Kate Taylor:</p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>When Anand Giridharadas was invited to speak at the National Association of Corporate Directors' annual summit, the writer —&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/anand-giridharadas-conscious-capitalism-2019-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"05da266dc59f144f335746eeb4fad8af\">known for his sharp critiques of billionaires and the global elite</a>&#160;— did not hold back.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>\"A lot of your children and grandchildren do not respect your work,\" Giridharadas said on Monday to more than 3,000 directors watching the summit virtually, according to audio obtained by Business Insider.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Giridharadas slammed directors for their lack of action, portraying businesses as making empty promises while simultaneously dodging responsibility.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>\"This being a group of corporate directors, I ask again, where were you?\" Giridharadas said in his remarks. \"Where were you in the run-up to the climate crisis? Where were you during widening inequality over the last four decades? Where were you in the run-up to the subprime crisis? Where were you in the run up to the opioid crisis? Where were you?\"</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>The aggressive remarks shocked many of the hundreds of people virtually attending the summit, which is billed as the \"the largest and most influential director forum in the world.\"</em></p><p>Read the story in full here:</p><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/writer-anand-giridharadas-slams-corporate-directors-2020-10\">Corporate board members demand refunds and threaten to 'rage quit' after writer Anand Giridharadas lambasts them in a virtual conference</a></strong></li></ul><hr><h1>Tech is coming to eat the $200 billion management-consulting industry</h1><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7b597e94fce90018f7b24f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"future of management consulting pandemic 2x1\" height=\"1200\" width=\"2400\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Samantha Lee/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>From Samantha Stokes:</p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>For decades, prestigious management-consulting firms like McKinsey, Bain, and BCG — collectively known as the Big 3 — have been an important part of the business world by advising clients and offering strategies for growth.&#160;</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>But the $200 billion consulting industry is facing a new threat: technology.&#160;</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>When it comes to information, expertise, insight and execution, technology is threatening to disrupt consulting firms' ability to offer services to clients at a high price tag.</em></p><p>Read the full story here:</p><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-technology-impacting-management-consulting-firms-disruption-future-jobs-2020-10\">Tech is coming to eat the $200 billion management-consulting industry's lunch. Here's a look at 4 factors disrupting how elite firms like BCG and McKinsey do business.</a></strong></li></ul><p>Also read:</p><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rich-lesser-ceo-bcg-climate-change-2020-10\">The CEO of Boston Consulting Group reveals the steps he's taking to address the global climate crisis, starting with a $400 million investment and a reduction in business travel</a></li></ul><hr><h2>An invitation</h2><p>The year 2020 has delivered surprises and shattered records at every turn — and the November elections could prove to be no different.&#160;</p><p>Join Business Insider on&#160;<strong>Wednesday, October 21 at 2 p.m. ET</strong>&#160;and hear from three investment experts who will share their advice on how to navigate the election-season peak.&#160;</p><p>Business Insider's Joe Ciolli will speak with Thomas Lee, managing partner and head of research for Fundstrat Global Advisors; Nancy Davis, founder and managing partner of Quadratic Capital Management; and James McDonald, CEO and chief investment officer of Hercules Investments.&#160;</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/webinar-how-to-invest-2020-election-strategies-stock-market-outlook-2020-10\">Register here.</a> </strong></p><p>Also read:</p><section><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-strategy-4-stocks-to-buy-market-leaders-nancy-zevenbergen-2020-10\">Nancy Zevenbergen is in the top 1% of investors over the past 5 years. She breaks down what she looks for in young companies — and shares 4 stocks she thinks could be market leaders 10 years from now.</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-companies-with-best-profit-growth-goldman-2020-10\">GOLDMAN SACHS: Buy these 15 stocks set to deliver the strongest possible profit growth and subsequent returns through year-end</a></li></ul></section><p>Here are some headlines from the past week you might have missed.&#160;</p><p>— Matt</p><hr><section><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/verkada-security-cameras-ipvm-investigation-2020-10\">Male employees at a $1.6 billion security-camera startup were accused of taking photos of female employees and sharing them in a private Slack channel</a></p><section><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/robert-f-smith-letter-vista-equity-investors-regarding-tax-turmoil-2020-10\">Read the full letter private equity titan Robert F. 2020 15:29:29 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f89bdd29e9fe40019009c49?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"9f92f8c4dab779f08372644d6dd8641b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn67@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-37-075_805bf68acf61fbc4.webp","destWidth":2993,"destHeight":2244,"sourceBytes":64548,"destBytes":64548,"author":"mturner@businessinsider.com (Matt Turner)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f89bd879e9fe40019009c46?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn88@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-19-743_70a8e83feeb29fbd.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ced637df2f4795c940a3ebe?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn3@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-22-265_ff545202126ca542.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7b597e94fce90018f7b24f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn55@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-36-449_8023d8af588cbec6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1BfBqa29V5s:v8TssO6AVls:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn71@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-30-490_c080a5e413a82a18.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1BfBqa29V5s:v8TssO6AVls:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn79@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-24-882_b0f979fdd9e96d48.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-26-187_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1BfBqa29V5s:v8TssO6AVls:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn12@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-28-935_13a1bc35f0fb9e7f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/1BfBqa29V5s":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn23@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-17-923_799192e867bf535b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520883},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Microsoft teamed up with a nonprofit using autonomous 'interceptor' boats to clean up the ocean and is helping it identify trash with machine learning","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/microsoft-machine-learning-for-the-ocean-cleanup-project-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c913094fce90018f7b5ac?format=jpeg\" alt=\"SFcleanup4\" height=\"2539\" width=\"3385\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ocean Cleanup in San Francisco.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Ocean Cleanup is a nonprofit that designs technology to clean up plastic from the ocean.&#160;</li>\n<li>Microsoft hosted two hackathons to build a machine learning model to help identify waste.</li>\n<li>The nonprofit is turning plastic ocean waste into new products.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Cleaning up the oceans is a huge undertaking, especially for a single nonprofit based out of the Netherlands, but having <a href=\"https://news.microsoft.com/features/microsoft-hackathon-leads-to-ai-and-sustainability-collaboration-to-rid-plastic-from-rivers-and-the-ocean/\">Microsoft</a> on your side is a nice bonus.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ocean-cleanup-project-failure-fixed-garbage-patch-2019-6\">Boyan Slat</a> launched <a href=\"https://theoceancleanup.com/\">The Ocean Cleanup</a> nonprofit in 2013, with the goal of cleaning up the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ocean-cleanup-catches-plastic-great-pacific-garbage-patch-2019-10\">Great Pacific Garbage Patch.</a> Since then, the project has also embraced the goal of preventing new waste from entering the ocean by cleaning up rivers the carry many of the pollutants.</p><p>In 2018, The Ocean Cleanup was a participant in Microsoft's annual hackathon, where volunteers work together on moonshots to try to come up with innovative solutions. The resulting machine learning models have helped The Ocean Cleanup track plastic and other waste, and informed how and where the nonprofit deploys its giant autonomous plastic collectors.&#160;</p><p>Take a look at how it works.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tThe Ocean Cleanup is a nonprofit taking on plastic pollution on two fronts: plastic already in the ocean, and plastic moving into the ocean through rivers.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d7979642e22af02ec40f684?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Plastic item floating in GPGP\" height=\"3239\" width=\"4319\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Garbage floating in the ocean.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tPlastic in oceans tend to form large systems like the Great Pacific Garbage Patch and break down into microplastics, which can be harmful to marine life and eventually people.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c984794fce90018f7b5ee?format=jpeg\" alt=\"plastic2\" height=\"2661\" width=\"3548\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ocean cleanup expedition.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAccording to The Ocean Cleanup, going after this waste with ships and nets would be expensive, time consuming, and require massive amounts of fossil fuels.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c989794fce90018f7b5ef?format=jpeg\" alt=\"plastic3\" height=\"2257\" width=\"3009\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ocean cleanup expedition.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tInstead, the project is working with what it calls a passive system for cleanup.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c9960282c500018c78de0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"inceptor\" height=\"2994\" width=\"3992\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Inceptor 001 in Jakarta.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tInterceptors like this one are part of the nonprofit's fleet.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c99b5282c500018c78de1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"inceptor3\" height=\"2992\" width=\"3989\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Inceptor 001 in Jakarta.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe solar powered vehicle autonomously collects plastic from rivers before it can reach the ocean, moving with river currents.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c9b71282c500018c78dee?format=jpeg\" alt=\"inceptor4\" height=\"2302\" width=\"3070\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Inceptor 001 in Jakarta.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tWith some already deployed in Jakarta and Malaysia, The Ocean Cleanup hopes to use interceptors on 1000 of the most polluting rivers around the world within five years.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c9b96282c500018c78df0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"interceptor002\" height=\"2661\" width=\"3548\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Interceptor 002 in Malaysia.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tVietnam and the Dominican Republic are the next sites.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c85f8282c500018c78d11?format=jpeg\" alt=\"interceptor002_5\" height=\"1705\" width=\"2560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Interceptor 002 in Malaysia.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tEach interceptor has a capacity of 65 cubic yards of waste and weighs nearly 50 tons.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5db6f955dee019434d2d0942?format=jpeg\" alt=\"The Ocean Cleanup River Device\" height=\"3456\" width=\"5184\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tDespite the massive size, the nonprofit says the interceptor is scalable because it was designed for mass production, can work in most of the world's polluting rivers, and requires only minimal human contact with dangerous pollutants.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c9e70282c500018c78e08?format=jpeg\" alt=\"interceptor002_9\" height=\"2658\" width=\"3545\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Interceptor 002 in Malaysia.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe interceptor is a kind of catamaran, where water continues moving with the current while concentrated plastic flows into the interceptor.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c9caa282c500018c78dfa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Ocean Cleanup Interceptor\" height=\"3502\" width=\"4670\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe current moves debris onto a permeable conveyer belt, leaving only pollutants behind.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c9d3394fce90018f7b61a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"interceptor002_2\" height=\"2661\" width=\"3548\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Interceptor 002 in Malaysia.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tDepending on the weather, current, and other factors a single interceptor can collect more than 11,000 pounds of debris in a day.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c9bce94fce90018f7b60a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"inceptor2\" height=\"2662\" width=\"3549\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Inceptor 001 in Jakarta.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tOnce full, the interceptor brings waste to shore to be sorted at a local facility.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c9f0394fce90018f7b633?format=jpeg\" alt=\"interceptor002_4\" height=\"2657\" width=\"3548\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Interceptor 002 in Malaysia.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThis is where Microsoft's help comes in. In 2018, Microsoft employee Drew Wilkinson reached out to The Ocean Cleanup by email about how the tech giant might help the nonprofit at its annual hackathon.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c9f9b94fce90018f7b641?format=jpeg\" alt=\"plasticCatch2\" height=\"1332\" width=\"1779\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Plastic accumulation.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t\"Microsoft has immense computational resources that could really help you track and monitor your efforts at a fraction of the cost using AI,\" he wrote in his outreach email.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7ca205282c500018c78e33?format=jpeg\" alt=\"plasticCatch\" height=\"2661\" width=\"3548\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Plastic accumulation.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://news.microsoft.com/features/microsoft-hackathon-leads-to-ai-and-sustainability-collaboration-to-rid-plastic-from-rivers-and-the-ocean/\">Microsoft</a></em></p>\n\tOver two company hackathons, Microsoft employees built a machine learning model to track plastic flowing through rivers with interceptors.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7ca26e94fce90018f7b659?format=jpeg\" alt=\"The Ocean Cleanup Malaysia\" height=\"3456\" width=\"4608\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBefore Microsoft's help, the nonprofit had one person labeling and identifying images of debris by himself, an inefficient and tedious process.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7ca2be94fce90018f7b660?format=jpeg\" alt=\"interceptor002_6\" height=\"720\" width=\"960\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Interceptor 002 in Malaysia.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe nonprofit shared images with Microsoft volunteers, who used the machine learning model to identify plastic versus other debris like leaves or branches.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7ca30f94fce90018f7b664?format=jpeg\" alt=\"SFcleanup\" height=\"3203\" width=\"4270\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ocean Cleanup in San Francisco.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIn one summer, they were able to label more than 30,000 photos.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c881d282c500018c78d2b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"plasticSorting\" height=\"1707\" width=\"2560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Plastic sorting.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tNow they're working on a similar model for ocean photos, too.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7ca36a94fce90018f7b666?format=jpeg\" alt=\"SFcleanup2\" height=\"2663\" width=\"3550\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ocean Cleanup in San Francisco.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tVessels in the ocean have a similar cleanup method and bring back debris to Mission Control in San Francisco for assessment.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7c913094fce90018f7b5ac?format=jpeg\" alt=\"SFcleanup4\" height=\"2539\" width=\"3385\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ocean Cleanup in San Francisco.\n<p class=\"copyright\">The Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tNow, The Ocean Cleanup is working to recycle the collected plastic into new products to keep the nonprofit financially sustainable.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7ca3c6282c500018c78e42?format=jpeg\" alt=\"granulate\" height=\"1444\" width=\"1926\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Plastic granulates.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ocean Cleanup</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 7c9d3394fce90018f7b61a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn47@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-31-178_f4299e8bc4c47b89.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7c9bce94fce90018f7b60a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn56@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-26-656_f26c08371e2ca467.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7c9f0394fce90018f7b633?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn28@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-34-490_514192e37c7e1cea.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7c9f9b94fce90018f7b641?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn83@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-32-434_210e8a57185925a3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7ca205282c500018c78e33?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn55@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-35-544_4b688e7f1b3d12f3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7ca26e94fce90018f7b659?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn72@2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-28-427_b37b0539d3ff7e2b.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7ca2be94fce90018f7b660?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn35@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-31-921_76c529322f17b1f4.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7ca30f94fce90018f7b664?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn32@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-21-373_c6eeb77705162523.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7c881d282c500018c78d2b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn11@2020_3/2020/10/18/17-02-29-823_b29e94406a69f7e4.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7ca36a94fce90018f7b666?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn27@2020_4/2020/10/18/17-02-32-635_d3f1a72af35418be.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7ca3c6282c500018c78e42?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn55@2020_1/2020/10/18/17-02-19-553_e08065ef2ab14a85.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/18/17-02-32-732_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=3UAqPx8MAQQ:WXT0N70Ig_w:F7zBnM 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"6 free online courses on diversity, equity, and inclusion to sign up for right now that will make you a better leader","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/free-online-courses-diversity-equity-inclusion-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f0c909b3ad8616e39065f67?format=jpeg\" alt=\"woman working on laptop\" height=\"1414\" width=\"2121\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>More companies are hiring leaders in diversity, equity, and inclusion.\n<p class=\"copyright\">mediaphotos/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) used to be an empty <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-stop-dismantle-systemic-racism-in-american-office-life-2020-6\">buzzword</a>, until the killing of George Floyd and the coronavirus pandemic forced leaders to <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/facebooks-advertising-crisis-shows-ceos-finally-listening-to-calls-equity-2020-6-1029355932#\">reckon with</a> racial injustice in the US.&#160;</li>\n<li>Now, Americans <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/heres-what-anti-racist-actions-workers-want-their-ceos-take-2020-7\">want leaders to prioritize</a> racial equity in the workplace.&#160;</li>\n<li>If you want to become a better manager, or set yourself up to become a leader within your company, it's important to have an understanding of DEI.&#160;</li>\n<li>Here are six free online courses on DEI from places like the University of Virginia, and the University of Pittsburgh.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) have been <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-stop-dismantle-systemic-racism-in-american-office-life-2020-6\">buzzwords in business for years</a>, with little results. That is, until the killing of George Floyd and a pandemic <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/facebooks-advertising-crisis-shows-ceos-finally-listening-to-calls-equity-2020-6-1029355932#\">awoke leaders</a> and the American public to massive <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/heres-what-anti-racist-actions-workers-want-their-ceos-take-2020-7'\">racial injustice</a>.</p><p>Now, more companies are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/companies-hiring-more-diversity-equity-inclusion-leaders-linkedin-data-2020-9\">hiring executives to lead the charge</a> on DEI. Leaders are making huge <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.in/international/news/a-mastercard-svp-shares-how-the-companys-recent-500-million-commitment-is-helping-to-close-the-racial-wealth-gap-in-the-us/amp_articleshow/78172622.cms\">financial commitments</a> to empower Black and Latino communities.&#160;</p><p>If you're a leader, manager, or a worker with goal of becoming a manager, it's important to know how to navigate a diverse workforce and be an inclusive person.</p><p>Business Insider combed through several popular learning websites to find several free courses on diversity, equity, and inclusion that can help make you a better leader.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tManaging a diverse team\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89c3f2d260780019341d98?format=jpeg\" alt=\"DEI course 6\" height=\"874\" width=\"1570\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Instructor Vanessa Womack is a co-author of &#34;The Female CEO&#34; and the founder of Vanessa Womack consulting group.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Linkedin Learning</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Institution: </strong>Linkedin Learning <strong>&#160;</strong></p><p><strong>Duration: </strong>1 day&#160;</p><p><strong>Time commitment:</strong> 1 hour 20 minutes&#160;&#160;</p><p>This introductory class is a great primer for managers with diverse teams. Students learn how to implement an open-door policy that encourages communication, how to work with multigenerational teams, how to identify negative behaviors that could derail your team, and using coaching tools to work with your direct reports.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/learning/managing-a-diverse-team/welcome\"><strong>Sign up here&#62;&#62;</strong>&#160;</a></p><p>&#160;</p>\n\tFoundations of diversity and inclusion\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89c220d260780019341d8b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"DEI course\" height=\"522\" width=\"932\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Laura Morgan Roberts is a professor at the University of Virginia&#39;s Darden School of Business.\n<p class=\"copyright\">UVA</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Institution: </strong>University of Virginia&#160;</p><p><strong>Duration:</strong> 2 weeks <strong>&#160;</strong>&#160;</p><p><strong>Time commitment: </strong>8 hours&#160;&#160;&#160;</p><p>This course explains how power and privilege play out in organizations, how companies can turn Black Lives Matter calls for action into new policies, how to have difficult conversations around race and power at work, and how to begin to root out bias in hiring practices.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/learn/foundations-of-diversity-and-inclusion-at-work-teachout#about\"><strong>Sign up here&#62;&#62;</strong></a></p>\n\tDiversity and inclusion in the workplace\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89c2aad260780019341d90?format=jpeg\" alt=\"DEI course 1\" height=\"523\" width=\"928\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Junko Takagi is the diversity and leadership chair at the ESSEC School of Business.\n<p class=\"copyright\">ESSEC</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Institution: </strong>ESSEC Business School</p><p><strong>Duration:</strong> 4 weeks&#160;</p><p><strong>Time commitment:</strong> 8 hours&#160;&#160;</p><p>This course starts with an overview of key diversity concepts, like LGBTQ issues in the workplace, disability inclusion, and how to avoid ageism and sexism in the workplace. Learners then begin to look at their own thought processes to examine their own bias and prejudice, to be a better leader. The course also includes a number of case studies around specific issues in certain countries, like LGBTQ issues in India, and ageism in the US.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/learn/diversity-inclusion-workplace#about\"><strong>Sign up here&#62;&#62;</strong> </a></p>\n\tGender and sexuality: Diversity and inclusion in the workplace\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89c30dd260780019341d93?format=jpeg\" alt=\"DEI course 3\" height=\"519\" width=\"925\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Susan Marine is an assistant professor and program director of the higher education master&#39;s program at Merrimack College.\n<p class=\"copyright\">University of Pittsburgh</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Institution: </strong>University of Pittsburgh&#160;</p><p><strong>Duration: </strong>4 weeks&#160;</p><p><strong>Time commitment:</strong> 15 hours&#160;&#160;&#160;</p><p>This class gives students an overview of gender and sexuality issues in the workplace. It starts with clear explanations on the differences between sex, gender, and sexuality, explains key terms, and includes quizzes. Students learn common examples of gender and sex stereotyping and discrimination, in order to avoid them, as well as a section on how to be an ally to the LGBTQ+ community.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/learn/gender-sexuality#about\"><strong>Sign up here&#62;&#62;</strong>&#160;</a></p>\n\tDiversity for dummies: making multiculturalism work\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89c356d260780019341d95?format=jpeg\" alt=\"DEI course 4\" height=\"1058\" width=\"1920\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Warren Chalklen is a diversity, equity, and inclusion online educator and the author of &#34;Reconsidering Roots.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Udemy</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Institution: </strong>Udemy <strong>&#160;</strong></p><p><strong>Duration: </strong>2-3 days &#160;</p><p><strong>Time commitment: </strong>2 hours</p><p>This course explores the benefits of diversity in an organization, how to develop an action plan to better incorporate diversity into your company, and anti-bias training in several key areas like race and ethnicity, gender, socio-economic status, and religion.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.udemy.com/course/diversity-for-dummies-making-multiculturalism-work/\"><strong>Sign up here&#62;&#62;</strong></a>&#160;</p>\n\tDiversity, inclusion, and belonging\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89c3999e9fe40019009c72?format=jpeg\" alt=\"DEI course 5\" height=\"877\" width=\"1565\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Pat Wadors is the chief talent officer at ServiceNow, an American software company.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Linkedin Learning</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>Institution: </strong>Linkedin Learning&#160;</p><p><strong>Duration: </strong>1 day&#160;&#160;</p><p><strong>Time commitment:</strong> 47 minutes&#160;</p><p>This course offers practical tips for engaging and retaining diverse talent, how to listen to your employees when issues arise, and how to encourage others at your organization to embrace a culture of diversity, equity, and inclusion.&#160;</p><p><a @2020_5/2020/10/18/17-02-35-062_64ccad124b88bfe1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/zlj1pIHJ30E":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_2/2020/10/18/17-02-32-729_73bc1d47d206a66d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603040520883},{"createdTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-19 01:02:00","title":"Federal inquiries, allegations of sexual assault, a resignation, and billions on the line: Here's everything you need to know about Nikola and its founder's controversial last 5 weeks","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/nikola-trevor-milton-controversies-gm-general-motors-deal-hindenberg-explained-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f892488d260780019341bf9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trevor milton mary barra\" height=\"666\" width=\"889\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>On the left, GM&#39;s CEO and chairman, Mary Barra. On the right, Nikola&#39;s founder and former CEO Trevor Milton.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Paul Sancya; REUTERS/Massimo Pinca</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Automotive giant General Motors and electric vehicle startup Nikola announced a $2 billion deal in early September.</li>\n<li>In the weeks since, Nikola and its founder, Trevor Milton, have been embroiled in controversy.</li>\n<li>Since then, Milton has stepped down as the executive Chairman of Nikola's board, and has faced additional accusations including lying and sexual assault.&#160;</li>\n<li>Nikola's stock has been battered by the allegations of fraud, with prices down more than 50% since the deal was announced Sept. 8.</li>\n<li>Negotiations are still underway between GM and Nikola. If the deal isn't done by December 3, then either side could walk away.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>In early September, automotive giant General Motors announced a $2 billion deal with electric-vehicle startup Nikola, with plans to produce the Nikola Badger, an electric pickup truck. But just two days after the deal was announced, a short seller released an explosive report claiming that Nikola faked its technological achievements, which spurred federal inquiries, a resignation, and speculation about the future of the deal.</p><p>Here's everything you need to know about the last month's controversy, and what it means for the future of GM, Nikola, and the electric truck they are looking to build.</p><h3><strong>The partnership begins: GM announces it's taking an 11% stake in Nikola on Sept. 8</strong></h3><p>On September 8, GM announced that it would begin a strategic partnership with Nikola in a $2 billion, all-stock deal. The terms of the agreement would see GM manufacture the startup's first pickup, the Badger, producing both the electric-battery and fuel-cell versions.</p><p><em>Do you work at GM or Nikola? Business Insider wants to hear from you. Contact the author of this report at ijibilian@businessinsider.com from a non-work email, or via secure messaging app Signal at 917-727-6830.</em></p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89a4afd260780019341c9a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"nikola badger 1\" height=\"1316\" width=\"1755\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Nikola Badger.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Nikola</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>For Nikola, a contract with America's largest Original Equipment Manufacturer by sales <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nikola-skepticism-thrown-out-window-2-billion-gm-deal-2020-9\">boosted credibility</a>, Wedbush analysts said, and its share prices. Following the announcement, Nikola's stock price <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/nikola-stock-price-gm-strikes-manufacturing-partnership-badger-general-motors-2020-9-1029569699\">jumped 53%</a>, Markets Insider previously reported.&#160;</p><p>For GM, the deal was supposed to pay for itself. Nikola would pay GM $700 million to engineer and manufacture the Badger, and in turn, GM could show off its Ultium battery in the new truck and collect 80% of the emissions credits for the vehicle. As part of the deal, GM would also be the exclusive provider of fuel cells for Nikola's semi-trucks, excluding Europe.</p><h3><strong>2 days later, Hindenburg Research released the explosive report, \"Nikola: How to Parlay An Ocean of Lies Into a Partnership With the Largest Auto OEM in America\"</strong></h3><p>Hindenburg research announced that it gathered \"extensive evidence\" that it said indicated that \"Nikola is an intricate fraud built on dozens of over the course of its Founder and Executive Chairman Trevor Milton's career\" on Sept. 10. The firm has a short position on Nikola, which means that it stands to profit if Nikola's share price goes down.</p><p><a href=\"https://hindenburgresearch.com/nikola/\">The report said</a> that Nikola made false or misleading claims about having proprietary battery technology, natural gas wells, solar panels, and hydrogen production capabilities. The report also said that while Milton claimed Nikola designed key components of its vehicles in house, the technology actually was licensed or bought from third parties.</p><p>In addition, Hindenburg Research said the Nikola's presentations of its semi-truck, the Nikola One, were \"a total farce.\" During one event, the electric vehicle company claimed that the truck's electrical systems worked, but Hindenburg's report said that there was an electrical cable under the stage secretly powering the truck.</p><p>Nikola also promoted a video of the semi-truck cruising down a road, but Hindenburg's report said that the truck was towed to the top of a hill, and then filmed as it rolled down to make it seem like it had a working motor.</p><p>On Sept. 10, Trevor Milton called the report a \"hit job\" on Twitter, and teased a swift rebuttal. \"Give me a few hours to put together responses to their lies,\" he wrote.</p><h3><strong>Four days after Milton's tweet, Nikola came out with an official statement saying Hindenburg's findings were \"false and misleading,\" while stating that they never claimed that the truck in its promotional video was \"under its own propulsion\"</strong></h3><p>In a statement published September 14, Nikola released a <a href=\"https://nikolamotor.com/press_releases/nikola-sets-the-record-straight-on-false-and-misleading-short-seller-report-96\">detailed response</a> to Hindenburg's report, saying that it \"was designed to provide a false impression to investors and to negatively manipulate the market in order to financially benefit short sellers, including Hindenburg itself.\"</p><p>In response to Hindenburg's claims that Nikola misrepresented third-party technology, specifically inverters, as its own, Nikola said that it had been designing its own inverters, but it \"does use third-party parts in prototype vehicles,\" and that it's \"common practice among vehicle manufacturers.\"</p><p>Responding to Hindenburg's claims that it had faked the capabilities of its Nikola One semi-truck, Nikola didn't dispute the claim that the truck had been rolled down a hill. Instead, Nikola said that they had never claimed that the vehicle was moving \"under its own propulsion\" or \"powertrain driven.\"&#160;</p><p>The next day, Hindenburg wrote that, \"the company debunked nothing,\" in a <a href=\"https://hindenburgresearch.com/nikola-response/\">statement</a> titled, \"We View Nikola's Response As a Tacit Admission of Securities Fraud.\"</p><h3><strong>Regulators, including the SEC and the DOJ, began examining fraud allegations</strong></h3><p>On September 14, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-14/sec-said-to-examine-nikola-over-short-seller-s-fraud-allegations?sref=LspfQlRv\">Bloomberg reported</a> that the SEC was conducting a preliminary review to see if Nikola broke any securities laws. The next day, the <a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/a45a6638-167b-4e27-a9fd-576e7229f959\">Financial Times reported</a> that the Department of Justice was looking into Hindenburg's allegations as well.&#160;</p><p>\"On September 11, Nikola's legal counsel proactively contacted and briefed the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) regarding Nikola's concerns pertaining to the Hindenburg report,\" a company spokesperson told Business Insider on Friday. \"Nikola welcomes the SEC's involvement in this matter.\"</p><h3><strong>Despite the controversy, GM projected confidence about its decision to strike a deal with Nikola on Sept. 15</strong></h3><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f892927d260780019341bfb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: General Motors Chairman and CEO Mary Barra makes a statement as members of the United Auto Workers bargaining committee listen at the start of contract talks between the union and automaker in Detroit, Michigan, U.S., July 16, 2019.  REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo\" height=\"537\" width=\"715\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>General Motors Chairman and CEO Mary Barra makes a statement as members of the United Auto Workers bargaining committee listen at the start of contract talks between the union and automaker in Detroit\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>\"We're a very capable team that has done the appropriate diligence,\" GM CEO Mary Barra said at an RBC event September 15, Business Insider's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nikola-fraud-short-sellers-hindenburg-research-general-motors-not-worried-2020-9\">Matthew DeBord reported</a>. Barra told attendees to go to Nikola with specific questions, but doubled down in her defense of GM's agreement with the startup, saying, \"on the strength of the deal we put together, it validates our technology, it allows us to have more people using the technology, which gives us the advantage of scale, which will help us drive costs down.\"</p><h3><strong>Following the controversy, Trevor Milton resigned from his position as executive chairman on Sept. 20</strong></h3><p>\"Nikola is truly in my blood and always will be, and the focus should be on the Company and its world-changing mission, not me,\" said <a href=\"https://nikolamotor.com/press_releases/nikola-board-of-directors-announces-leadership-transition-97\">Milton in a September 20 statement</a>. \"So I made the difficult decision to approach the Board and volunteer to step aside as Executive Chairman.\"</p><p>Stephen Girsky, who previously served on GM's Board of Directors, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nikola-trevor-milton-resignation-positive-for-long-term-vision-analysts-2020-9\">took over Milton's role.</a></p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8928f1d260780019341bfa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Nikola chairman Trevor Milton with CNH Industrial CEO Hubertus Muhlhauser at an event in Italy\" height=\"760\" width=\"1013\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Founder of U.S. Nikola Trevor Milton attends a news conference at an event in Turin, Italy, December 3, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Massimo Pinca</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>As part of his sudden departure from Nikola, Milton, who is the largest shareholder of Nikola, gave up company equity valued at $166 million at the time,&#160; a $20 million consulting contract with the company, while continuing to hold Nikola stock valued at $3.1 billion at the time, <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/21/nikola-founder-trevor-milton-forfeits-166-million-in-stock-and-gets-to-keep-3point1-billion-under-separation-deal.html\">CNBC reported</a>. Nikola will also cover Milton's legal fees, under certain stipulations.</p><h3><strong>Later that day, Milton's cousin accused him of sexually assaulting her</strong></h3><p>Aubrey Smith <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nikola-founder-trevor-milton-cousin-accuses-him-sexual-assault-2020-9\">told Business Insider</a> that Milton assaulted her in 1999, after their grandfather's funeral service. Smith was 15 and Milton was 17, according to prior <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nikola-founder-trevor-milton-cousin-accuses-him-sexual-assault-2020-9\">Business Insider reporting</a>. Under the guise of giving her a massage, Milton took off Smith's bra without her consent and then groped her, Smith said.&#160;</p><p>In the weeks following Smith's allegation, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nikola-founder-trevor-milton-second-sexual-assault-allegation-report-2020-9\">another woman came forward</a> accusing Milton of sexual assault, <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/29/two-women-file-sexual-abuse-complaints-against-nikola-founder-trevor-milton.html\">CNBC reported</a>. She alleged that Milton digitally penetrated her against her consent in 2004 when she was 15 and he was 22. She was an employee at his security company at the time, her lawyer told CNBC.&#160;</p><p>Milton denied both of the claims in a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nikola-founder-trevor-milton-second-sexual-assault-allegation-report-2020-9\">prior statement to Business Insider</a>. \"At no point in his life has Mr. Milton ever engaged in any inappropriate physical contact with anyone,\" Milton's representative wrote.</p><p>\"The Nikola Board first learned of these allegations, regarding conduct from before Nikola was founded, from tweets and media reporting that occurred subsequent to the company's announcement that Trevor Milton was stepping aside as Executive Chairman,\" a Nikola representative told Business Insider. \"Nikola has been and remains committed to creating a safe, respectful, and inclusive work environment for all employees and has established policies and procedures to instill these values throughout the company.\"</p><h3><strong>A report surfaces Sept. 26 alleging Trevor Milton purchased the designs for the Nikola One semi-truck, rather than designing it himself \"in his basement,\" as previously claimed</strong></h3><p>The <a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/9bd5e3f3-4d09-458c-b390-bc94b1f4a024?campaign_id=4&emc=edit_dk_20200928&instance_id=22589&nl=dealbook&regi_id=71823306&segment_id=39220&te=1&user_id=f058385abc0a81f5ba25805ecd26bcd9385abc0a81f5ba25805ecd26bcd9\">Financial Times reported</a> that the founder purchased the design for the Nikola One from Adriano Mudri, a designer employed at the Croatian electric vehicle brand Rimac Automobili. Nikola had previously claimed that Milton had created the design for the truck himself in a 2018 lawsuit against Tesla.&#160;</p><p>\"The Nikola One truck was designed and patented by Nikola. It is commonplace to license third-party designs during vehicle development, and although early in the process, Nikola purchased a license to Adriano Mudri's designs,\" a Nikola representative told Business Insider on Friday.&#160; \"He was not part of the design team, and his designs are materially different from the design invented by Nikola for the Nikola One.\"</p><h3><strong>Negotiations are still underway for the deal between GM and Nikola. The companies missed their Sept. 30 initial target date for finalizing the agreement.</strong></h3><p>Nikola's share price has been battered by the fraud allegations, with shares of Nikola down 53% since the partnership was announced, as of Thursday. CNBC's <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/nikola-stock-price-report-general-motors-could-take-bigger-stake-2020-9-1029636618\">Phil LeBeau reported Sept. 30</a> that GM might take a bigger stake in Nikola, given the fact that Nikola's share price has dropped precipitously since the deal was announced. GM's proposed 11% stake was worth about $2 billion when the deal was penned. Now, it's worth less than half that much.&#160;</p><p>\"Our transaction with Nikola has not closed,\" a GM rep said on September 29, according to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gm-says-it-is-continuing-discussions-with-nikola-on-alliance-deal-2020-9\">Reuters</a>. \"We are continuing our discussions with Nikola and will provide further updates when appropriate or required.\"</p><p>On Thursday, a Nikola executive \"played down\" the significance of the Badger project, <a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/a93d512e-54b0-41d3-aadb-7a101605fb55\">the Financial Times reported</a>. \"The Badger was an interesting and exciting project to some shareholders, but our institutional shareholders are mostly focused on the business plan,\" said Nikola's CEO Mark Russell, according to the Financial Times. Russell also said Thursday that the Badger wouldn't be built without an OEM partner like GM, according to <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-16/nikola-ceo-says-startup-s-plans-intact-even-if-gm-deal-unravels?srnd=premium&sref=LspfQlRvQlRv\">Bloomberg</a>. Russell also told Bloomberg that the company can carry on even if the GM deal falls apart.&#160;</p><p>GM did not immediately respond to a request for comment.</p><p>\"Nikola continues to work with GM towards a closing and will provide further updates when appropriate or required,\" a Nikola representative told Business Insider on Friday.</p><p>If the deal isn't done by Dec. 3, either company could walk away.&#160;</p><p><em>Do you work at GM or Nikola? Business Insider wants to hear from you. Contact the author of this report at ijibilian@businessinsider.com using a non-work email, or via the secure messaging app Signal at (917) 727-6830.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Kz1ZVwWdwn8:HFqRRavEY4E:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Kz1ZVwWdwn8\"
